column10:
This game is absolutely amazing. The art is beautiful, the characters are cute, and the atmosphere is so comfy. The dialogue between the characters are also hilarious and capture the whimsical feel of the Touhou universe. There are also lots of character cameos and it's great that the game focuses on one of the lesser known characters and her friend.

Absolute must-have if you are a Touhou fan. Also an amazing game if you are interested in restaurant simulators with cute comfy storylines. It's a relaxing game that does offer some challenge to keep your brain engaged as you explore Gensokyo.

10/10. Would take a loan and risk my kneecaps with Chen again to save my best friend.

I have never played Touhou but this is an incredible restaurant manager. The gameplay loop is simple but rewarding, the art and music are incredible, the characters are neat even when I don't already know them, and the game is insanely cheap for the amount of content, especially on sale (which it often is). I am genuinely surprised by how much I love this.

Extraordinarily fun. The soundtrack is fantastic. The pixel art is detailed and well-crafted. The gameplay is addictive. It's cute and funny. Expansive DLCs. It's a great introduction for anyone who wants to get into Touhou. Sometimes I just sit and listen to the music. Highly recommend. Play this game. Even if you're not interested in Touhou, it's still a load of fun. I love it.

I started this game without expecting much, just a simple "short" relaxing game to play in between other big titles.

And I've never being happier to have been proven wrong.

This game is quite simple in it's gameplay loop: collect ingredients, speak with Touhou characters to deepen your friendship with them and, at night, serve your customers at your izakaya to pay your debts and, hopefully, earn some cash to make the concert of your dreams turn into a reality. But it's that simple loop that makes it so enjoyable to play. The game goes easy on the player. It's quite easy to become filthy rich once you unlock a couple of the izakaya upgrades (for example, I finished the game with 60K yen after buying every single possible upgrade I could find).

Another of it's stronger points is in it's ambience: warm, cozy, gorgeous pixelart accompanied by a wonderful OST, all great stuff. Despite some broken English (which I can overlook, this is a fangame and is translated by fans for fans after all), it's writing is another of it's stronger parts, if not the strongest. Chatting with every character always felt distinct and special, no matter who it was.

And, need I remind you, all of this is just the main game. I still have to tackle all the DLCs.
Of which there are 6.
And it's a FANGAME.

It's an honest to god bargain of an amazing game (I even think I didn't pay enough for what it actually is), and I highly recommend it to anyone interested in either Touhou Project as a whole or anyone looking for a cozy experience, since you need basically almost zero Touhou knowledge to join in on the fun, the game is very good in it's writing that you'll get the gist of almost everything without needing to look for info outside the game.

10/10 and probably my GOTY for games that haven't released in 2024.

This is a super cute little game where you manage an Izakaya. Whilst it is set in the world of Touhou, a franchise I am only very vaguely familiar with, I still found the story easy to understand with my limited preexisting knowledge.
The artwork is wonderful, every character and environment is well drawn in a very appealing pixel style, and are all very very veryyyy cute!!
I splurged to get all the DLC, which is still a very affordable price with a whopping 6 (?) DLC packs that bring new areas! However, the base game is still a very expansive and worthwhile map without--and very cheap.
I highly recommend this game to anyone who would like a cute little slice of life to play!

This game has an addictive play cycle, and I was enjoying it, until two hours in one of the NPCs compared asked whether she looks like Christ crucified and I was like, "Welp, I'm out." I normally play games as a perfectionist which is very tiresome, but this game is all trial and error (and it's roughly 20 minutes between saves). it's the first game where I actually don't just go back to my last save when I don't reach 100% of my goal and that's amazing for me!

WHERE'S THE HEADPAT BUTTON

There are few games I'd recommend more. 10/10, minor flaws but if you are a touhou fan and even somewhat enjoy more casual games, or you like the restaurant sim genre... Play it. Play it. Buckle in, this review may get a bit long.

Price isn't something I usually bring up immediately. But, this game is SIX. DOLLARS. And regularly goes on sale for under five dollars.

That is utterly absurd price to content ratio, only matched by a game like hollow knight. Even if you pick this game up and only complete half of the basegame content, you are still making out like a bandit. And it's not just the basegame- The DLCs, each of which contains a hefty amount of content in their own right, are three dollars, and themselves go on sale for two dollars.

At the time of writing, I have 122 hours in this game, and have experienced all the content in the basegame, 3 of the dlcs, and most of the fourth dlc. If you really enjoy this game, you can get the game and all its dlcs for under twenty five dollars. That is absurd, to the point where I almost feel like I'm cheating the devs out of money!

Beyond the absolute steal of a price, the game's presentation is phenomenal. Beautiful, stylized pixel art with great detail, including full-page art at many points during the base game and dlcs. Lively and upbeat music that arranges touhou tracks in great ways. This game has a very distinct style that is very good, and very comfy.

Furthermore, the story is fantastic. If you're a fan of touhou's world and its characters, you will love this game. Across the basegame and DLCs, there's very few characters I'd say are presented out of character, which is a rarity for touhou fangames. But it goes above and beyond just matching how the characters are portrayed- it expands on them. This game has given me an appreciation for certain characters I didn't care for before, just based on how it writes them. This game also excels at character variety, giving love to underrepresented touhou characters too!

There's a staggering amount of attention to detail here- it's very clear the devs are very passionate about touhou, and that love for the series oozes into every part of this game. It's amazing how characters will organically talk about things in their conversations, only for me to realize that they were referencing an obscure part of a touhou written work or game- the devs clearly know their stuff in regards to touhou.

There are certain parts of Gensokyo's world and characters they modify slightly for this game's premise, so if you're a huge lore fan, don't be surprised by that. It's not out of ignorance- I feel like these are intentional changes the devs made to keep this games cozy atmosphere, in a world that can somewhat dark at times. But, I don't think that's a bad thing. In this comfy rendition of Gensokyo, Yokai don't eat humans, more sinister characters are less devious, and the friction between humans and yokai is overall much less intense.

Last: Gameplay. There's a reason I bring it up last, and that's because, compared to what I mentioned above, it's this games weakest link. Don't get me wrong; I don't think the gameplay is bad. Rather, it is only "Very good". Only, that "Very Good" Seems worse in comparison to the absolutely overflowing quality present everywhere else in this game.

The game is very comfy, and satisfying. The restaurant sections, the main gameplay draw, usually wont be demanding your full attention, but they are still fun- and during certain busier nights, it begins to become hectic in a very fun way.

That being said, the difficulty is a concern. I would say that in general the game is too easy, but still enjoyable despite that. (I wouldn't call it boring...) With just a few changes- most notably , a nerf to the buffs you gain from doing the rhythm minigames, I feel like it could be a lot more challenging in a rewarding way, but I also understand that a big draw of this game is its casual, comfy nature, and I wouldn't want to take that away.

So, if I must be greedy, and ask for more from this game already overloaded with content... A hardmode would be nice. I don't think it's going to happen, but its one of the small changes I'd make if I could.

That being said, if you want the game to be a little more challenging, there's plenty of restrictions you can impose on yourself to do that. (Restrictions that would be active automatically in a proposed hardmode) Stuff like being unable to give the same rare guest the same dish twice in a sitting, or having restrictions on the partners you have available. 

Beyond the restaurant sections, this also extends into other aspects of the game- most notably, the budgetary concerns. There's realistically no way to not make your debt off (You often make that much money in just one night) so the threat of a game over is sort of superficial. But, that's honestly not a big deal.

Despite the game being pretty easy elsewhere, the boss fights are legitimately challenging, and there's one for each DLC, too, so it's not completely without difficulty. If you're finding parts of the game too easy for your liking, look forward to them!

So yeah, I recommend the HECK out of this game.

TL;DR: What you get for what you pay - on sale or not - worth. If you like restaurant and time management games, go for it. If you like Touhou, bonus points.

Pros:
Controllable difficulty via gameplay freedom
Art is cute - food and characters
Music gud 
Extra costumes worth getting, and I hate extra cosmetics normally - done via gameplay
Has consumed my life for the last 2 weeks
Can scratch the micro-manage itch, or the Zen itch - your choice.
Even has a mini rhythm game to scratch that itch too
Smol birb conquers gods and demons that could kill you with a cough with food.

Cons:
UI clarity can be awkward when there are a lot of things happening on screen - almost thematic to its bullet hell source material?
Epilepsy warning - probably mentioned in game somewhere, but putting it here just in case
Crashes- hard and soft seemingly at random - devs give instructions how to report bugs directly, first time I've actually bothered reporting things wrong in a game
Saves are hard locked after each day - not a problem if stability was perfect - however due to the freedom allowed in game to change things up, frustration when crashing was lower as I'd just choose something different so repetition didn't sour it overall.

Note: This game has liberated me from AAA malaise, now part of indie religion. Gonna get DLC because game has earned it.

First, a disclaimer: as of right now all the content has been released, [i]however[/i] most translations are still incomplete, including English (you [i]will[/i] see and have to deal with quests and descriptions in Chinese).

This is a very cute restaurant management game where you'll spend half of the time gathering ingredients, and another half preparing food/serving your customers. It may sound simple, but the variety of your ingredient stock and quests will force you to tweak your menu and shop setup quite frequently, and then there are some mini-games on top to keep you busy. There are mini-games as side activities as well, including one very extensive rhythm game similar to Taiko the tatsujin.

All the touhou girls are super cute, and the dialogs are hilarious. There's tons of events and optional things to unlock. But at the same time, you can always scale down if you feel overwhelmed.

The save system is a bit weird and may be inconvenient: the only time you can save your progress is before you start the next day, which can take quite some time to complete (especially if you have some special event). Cloud saves are also implemented weirdly and may fail to work (often an issue if you have Steam Deck).

I purchased this game, ooh, probably almost two years ago. Being in college, I didn't get to spend much time with it. However, I've been back into playing regularly, and it's one of my favorites to relax. It scratches that Dinner Dash itch that I sometimes get, but adds the elements of gathering and building the recipes yourself that I really enjoy in games like Potion Permit and Stardew Valley. My comparisons to those games are light, but those are the elements of those 3 games combined that really make it fun. Even with the long break in between from when I started playing and now (and barely remembering the storyline), the game was really easy to jump back into. I see some reviews being upset about the repetitive nature of the game, but isn't that the point? Practice makes perfect and sometimes you just want to play a game that you can autopilot on. As long as you maintain the main quests, you can take as long as you want with any other quests. 

Did I forget to mention the characters are so cute? The music is also sooo good.

There's just so much to do in this game, the base game alone has hours upon hours of content! The gameplay loop is simple if not a bit repetitive, but fun. I'd find myself getting into a routine, only to realize I completely forgot a task because I'm a bird-brain! It's not very hard either, so it can be pretty relaxing. The story is simple but cute, and you don't need any familiarity with 2hu to understand it. In fact, this game is a pretty good introduction to Gensokyo and its lovable cast! The English translation is also pretty good, with only occasional grammatical errors and spelling mistakes.

No matter if you're a well-versed 2hu fan or completely clueless, I highly recommend it! You won't regret it~

Ah "东方夜雀食堂" or "Touhou Mystia's Izakaya" in english, where should i start? It's got everything in it that i enjoy.

Touhou universe, restaurant management gameplay, with a few gimmicks here and there and sprinkled with a good amount of funny interactions between the loveable characters in this cute setting.

This is no danmaku, unlike other Touhou games but it's just as entertaining and satisfying once you master it.

You are playing as Mystia, a bird-youkai that resides in "Youkai Trail" and opens up her small Izakaya at night.
One thing lead to another and you see yourself all of a sudden in debt, a running joke until the end of the game.

The gameplay-loop is to gather and buy resources during the day and then make money during the night, throughout the game you'll encounter more and more characters which will eventually visit your Izakaya as "Rare Guests". Here you need to learn what they like and dislike, you are given small hints each time they order and if you successfully match what they ask for you are being rewarded with spellcards. There are some crazy combinations that can be done, that'll help you fill up your pockets faster.

As for music, the game offers are vast amount and for a touhou game, good music is a given here. You'll not be disappointed.

All in all, the game is very much enjoyable even if you never heard about Touhou before. I'd like to think it's probably even something that gets you interested in it once you start playing because it is such a fantastic game.

The graphics are cute and the restaurant gameplay is pretty intensive. The rhythm aspect, which happens sporadically, gets old quickly as your mind is probably more preoccupied with thinking about making orders. The game also does a good job of changing things up, with events affecting cuisine demand (like Recettear).

The controls are clunky though, especially playing with a controller. Opening a menu/window doesn't guarantee the highlighted box is where you'll expect it to be (starts at random places), screen/control labels vibrate intensely if you try to use your mouse to get around the clunky controls, and sometimes the interface freezes. During the dining rushes, it's frustrating dealing with the controls problems and rhythm game when I'm just trying to fulfill orders. I've found that just exiting and reentering the interface until it works tends to be the most simplest way to address the issue.

That said, it's fun and I think the entertainment you get out of the gameplay matches the price.

A very cute game that runs smoothly with a pleasant soundtrack and cute characters. I'm a very, very casual Touhou fan and I still thoroughly enjoy the atmosphere and the quirky characters. 

As far as I know, I'm not super far into the game as of writing this review, but so far the gameplay hasn't been too challenging. It's not mindless by any means, but even when managing a lot of stations + large menu, and a full-size izakaya, it's actually surprisingly manageable even if you do start to feel the tension. 

It's a cute, relaxing game that keeps you engaged with a satisfying gameplay loop. 

The only vice I can think of is that keyboard controls are a little clunky. Even though they are fully customizable, some actions are bound to each other for no reason, and sometimes a binding for one key would be more logical in one gameplay mode (when you're just exploring and gathering ingredients) rather than the other (when you're running the restaurant). This is, however, an extremely minor complaint given that I have a USB controller and it is much more comfortable that way (the game seems to be optimized for that moreso than keyboard) -- I highly recommend using one if you have one.

If you are only using a keyboard, I would actually recommend mapping the controls to something more old-school that uses the arrow keys for movement and the rest of the keyboard for all of the other functions. It felt more intuitive to me that way.

One of the best non-bullet hell Touhou fan games I've played. An incredibly high quality time management and restaurant sim. Even if you aren't familiar with the Touhou Project game series, this game can be enjoyed all the same.

-The gameplay loop is very solid and nicely casual, so it's very easy to relax to. Though it does have it's challenges here and there.
-The art is very nice and the locations you unlock as you progress are very well made, and the cutscene art is also great.
-The music completely steals the show with how amazing it is. Every track is unique and are bangers through and through. One of the very few times I've bought the soundtrack for a video game at full price.
-The story isn't too deep but doesn't really need to be. It's serviceable but certainly not dull. The character dialog is really endearing and the conversations feel very natural.

Overall a great deal for 6 dollars. The DLC's are also high quality and expand the game in great ways.

This game is a derivative work of the Touhou Project series, set in the universe of Touhou and the vast majority of characters minus two or three are all from this doujin series.

[h1] GAMEPLAY [/h1]
Your day is divided into two sections;
Daytime: where you go around collecting ingredients, bonding with characters and running some errands for them, you have an ingame clock that starts at 10:00 in the morning, each time you collect something or ask someone to do something for you time advances by 30 minutes, at 18 the daytime ends.
Nighttime: Here is where the game really starts; you set up your Izakaya (Food stand) by choosing a location, the recipes you want to serve that night and drinks, and your goal is to satisfy all of your costumers AKA "Guests" from 18:00 to midnight. normal guests will ask you for food that you have selected for that night, but every once in a while a RARE guest will appear, they are characters from the Touhou Project series this fan game is based on, and rather than asking for a recipe on the menu they will vaguely tell you what flavor they want to eat, and if you manage to satisfy their demands they'll reward you by casting a SPELLCARD, these will give you various benefits ranging from giving you free ingredients to other passive boosts that will generally help you out, on the other side serving them stuff they dislike will trigger a negative Spellcard that will harm you in some way.
Aside from the main story you get a "mini" story of sorts with your rare guests, each character has 5 level of "Bond" that increased each time you serve them dishes they like at your Izakaya, each time you max out a level of bond, you need to carry out some errands for them to unlock the next level, by bonding with them you can unlock new recipes and passive abilities and the option to ask them to come over to your Izakaya or to gather stuff like food and drinks for you.

[h1] STORY AND CHARACTERS [/h1]
I won't spoil the story, but it is a light-hearted and wholesome one, the characters are well written, despite the fact that this game is not bound by the canon of Touhou because of its nature as a fan work, the characters are most of the time in line with their canon counterparts, with the occasional small deviation but nothing too drastic.

[h1] SOUNDTRACK [/h1]
The OST of this game mainly consists of remixes of songs from Touhou, and they're all great at that, i have yet to find a track that i dislike! Each location explorable during daytime has its own theme, you will be also listening to 3 different tracks during different situation in your Izakaya while you serve tasty food.

[h1] DLC CONTENT [/h1]
The game has currently 5 DLCs with a 6 and final one that is planned for release in 2024
these are DLC1 through 4 and  DLC 2.5 which adds a rhythm minigame for all the OST of the game.
Each of DLC1, 2, 3 and 4 will add the following;
2 new locations with new ingredients and their respective new OSTs for daytime and nighttime gameplay
6 new bond characters, with new dish recipes and passive abilities as rewards tied to their bond levels
2 new unlockable partners
A "Boss" fight that once beaten, can be re-challenged with a greater difficulty in case the base game is too easy for one's taste
These DLCs add around 15-20 hours of extra gameplay, but they can be played alongside the main story without finishing the game, this holds true for all of them but DLC1, which has to be played after you beat the main game. For the price of 2.81 € i highly recommend them if you've finished the game and still yearn for more.

[h1] CLOSING THOUGHTS [/h1]
Mystia's Izakaya offers around 25-30 hours of gameplay without counting its DLCs, for its full price of 5,81 € it is worth every cent, this is without questions one of the absolute best Touhou fan games out there, and it is completely enjoyable even without prior knowledge of the series or characters, while Touhou fans will still get their honey with the care and love that the dev has for the series' lore.

[h1]  Here is a review of the game from a person who is not qualified to write reviews in any way. [/h1] 


[h2]  Gameplay: [/h2] 
  A very charming & fun cooking game with some light rythm game mechanics that can get quite a bit harder later in the story when you upgrade your izakaya.
You are not forced to use the upgraded izakayas if you want the experience to be more relaxing.

[h2] Story & Characters: [/h2] 
  The game has a lighthearted story that isn't very complex. The game has a lot of different characters with their own pieces of story.

[h2] Music & Sound: [/h2] 
  The soundtrack while is quite enjoyable and fits the game very well. The sound effects while cooking are actually very good and make the experience a whole lot more fun.

[h2] Downsides: [/h2] 
  The only downside I can think of is that you can only save at the end of each day but that is not a deal breaker and it is there to prevent players from softlocking themselves.

[b] tldr: [/b]
Overall if you like a game with a relaxing atmosphere and cute and quirky characters alongside some pretty 2D art this is the game for you. I recommend the game even if you are not familiar with Touhou characters, though you might miss some references.  

(+The game is very cheap for the amount of hours you can pour into it.)

This is a game about plundering the world of its natural resources and stealing the crops of others' labour, before throwing said resources onto a cutting board and conjuring vile amalgamations of rice, the moulted shells of cicadas, raw egg and uncooked meat, which you then proceed to serve to your closest friends for profit (friends do NOT get discounts) so as to keep your kneecaps intact and pay off debt after debt whose value is constantly increasing, ostensibly due to inflation.

Build up superficial relationships with your favourite Touhou characters, and when they can comfortably consider you one of their best friends, waste no time in exploiting them by sending them on plundering expeditions, rewarding them for their efforts with nothing but a brief thank you. If they for any reason exhibit hesitation towards being exploited thus, always remember that their insecurities work to your advantage.

Jokes aside, this is a cute and charming game with incredible pixel graphics and great music. Sure, one might find it repetitive at times, but this is, after all, a casual game, and it's relaxing and enjoyable nonetheless. The dialogue is wholesome, and interacting and bonding with the characters within the world is fun and rewarding. As you browse through your album of in-game friends and gaze in satisfaction at your various max bond levels, you are reminded of the cruel reality that you do not possess any friends in the real world, and must resort to seeking respite within a fictional one.

Anyway, I would genuinely highly recommend this game to anyone, regardless of their familiarity with the Touhou universe. I personally knew next to nothing about Touhou when I bought this game, but found great enjoyment in playing it nonetheless, so much so that I went ahead and purchased every one of the DLCs.

By the way, if you are planning to buy and 100% the game, here's a quick but important tip:
Be sure to keep save files at 03/14 and 03/24 (MM/DD). Also, Mystia's house has a basement! I only discovered that halfway through my playthrough.

Never did I expect myself to spend as much time on a Touhou fan-game (that isn't Touhou Luna Nights) as much as this one. It's easily one of the most charming and engaging Touhou fan-games I've played in a while. Whether it be managing multiple customers or strengthening your bond with Sanae Kochiya, this game never stops getting boring, especially after you get out of the Youkai Trail and start opening up more shops in other familiar locations in Gensokyo. The music is relaxing, the mechanics regarding certain customers are (mostly) brilliant, the punishments are funny (and cruel when it's one of your favs that punishes you 😭), and the partners you can unlock (especially in the DLCs) is great. Also gotta love the random pop-culture references they just sprinkle into the game and also the PC-98 representation here.

My only gripe is that the translation can sometimes be confusing for some of the rare customers and their needs (unless you use a guide, which I'd highly recommend if you care about maxing out your bonds. Trust me, it's worth it), but I can let it slide 'cuz it ain't easy to get a game translated if you're not primarily an English speaker (I know how bad translations can be as a Mega Man fan. lmao).

Perhaps it's not the best game for someone's first introduction to the series, but it's a great game for fans, and I highly recommend it!!! HOMIES, GAS THIS GAME UP!!!

Juggling with your hobby (cooking) to earn enough money in order to achieve your dreams (concert), you juggle a daily life of foraging and preparing your Izakaya to server customers as the (literally) bird-brain Mystia in this game. Alongside the daily life of moving around the map to forage and serve customers, it seems like Mystia gets further and further down the debt rabbit hole with the money-grubbing Chen and her pre-made contracts of expanding branches and that unavoidable premium bunny merchant who eats on your restaurant but makes you purchase more than the amount she eats.

This game delves first-hand into a simulation managing your finances (and debts), all the while saving up for your restaurant costs while balancing your daily life of dealing with customers and VIPs that might help or destroy you.

++ The DLCs are a great supplement and extension to the main game. Lots of new characters, ingredients, dishes & places to explore. Would recommend 10000/10.

What a cute Touhou-theme restaurant management game. You play as Mystia Lorelei, a youkai night sparrow, gather ingredients, cook food, make money, complete objectives, the game executed everything it does extremely well! Accompanying the gameplay with beautiful and cute artworks, environments and awesome music. It's just overall awesome even for people who don't know much about Touhou (like myself).

[h1]In short[/h1]
The game opens with a hook that some incident is going on in Gensokyo (again) but this time everything somehow hinges on Mystia and her... izakaya?! What could cooking has to do with saving Gensokyo? That's for the player needs to find out through the story.

The game got a well-paced tutorials with both main and side objectives that really aren't too difficult, the game accommodates players who just want to chill and make food as a youkai bird well, stress-free!.... even if the story puts Mystia into debt. There's a wide variety of characters you can interact with including both popular and lesser known Touhou characters with their own personality. 

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
For those looking for a nice, chill and warming experience, Mystia's Izakaya is a great fit, almost like a slice-of-life anime in restaurant management game form.

If you're looking to get stressed out by debts and responsibilities, you can play the game like that, too, but then you'll get drowned in money unlike real life. 

Sidenote, the developers have been keeping this game updated with new contents for very reasonable prices, the developers showed that they love this game and want give the player even more to play with! Even in 2023, so much more contents have been added!

[h1]Extra thoughts[/h1]
[b]Narratively[/b], you're not going to find any major WTF twists and turns here, most people probably can guess the general plot of the game within the first 10 minutes! But that's not a bad thing, the story is a slice-of-life for the most parts, where Mystia just interacts with other characters both through the story and also just by talking to them as she collects ingredients. The comedy and fluff never gets stale (for me, anyway) right until the end.

[b]Mechanically[/b], each in game day is split into 30-minutes segments. Don't worry if this sounds complicated, the game takes you through each new mechanic slowly! Overall, it's just the matter of serving the right food and drink and make money, feel free to skip the list because I just summarised the game's tutorials.
[list]
[*]The first phase, starting from 10:00 and ending at 18:00 will have Mystia going around the map, collecting ingredients, talking to people and visiting shops with more areas will unlock over time. Collecting ingredients and moving between areas will cost you 30 minutes, so it's good to prioritise tasks that don't cost time first!
[*]The second phase goes up to midnight, which is when Mystia will open her Izakaya. Before opening, though, you'll need to pick menu items, drinks and cookware to use on the day (you can level up and upgrade the Izakaya to get more slots). You'll be able to pick partners, too, to help running the Izakaya, either by serving food, drink or cooking (though personally I find having partners serve is more efficient than cooking). 
[*]Normal guests can be satisfied by just giving the right items, but you'll rare guests (Touhou characters) that give you their preferences for food and drinks, then you have to cook the right food (not necessarily on the menu that day) with perhaps extra ingredients and drinks. 
[*]Rare guests will reward you with Spell Cards (buffs) or Punishments (debuffs) that may make your night better (or worse). 
[*]Oh, and there's also a rhythm minigame when cooking that you can do to get buffs, but once you get all buffs, you'll get one big super buff called Hyper Mode and won't have to do the minigame again until the effect expires.
[/list]

[b]Graphically[/b], the game uses pixel arts, from the sprites to portraits to the environments, everyone and everything looks amazing, from cute to cool, take your pick. Nothing to complain about there, there are story artworks that looks amazing as well that you could even use as wallpapers.

[b]Audio[/b]... the music is just great, played through the entire game and I never got tired of the music, having a Touhou fangame with great music just feels perfect. The music is generally cute and cheerful for the most part, some other parts calming and peaceful. It probably can help cheering you up. All the sound effects are nice and fitting, nothing extraordinary but nothing to complain about, either!

A charming mix of pixel style and great remixes. It was a relaxing game in the same vein as Stardew Valley, and scratched that same itch it satisfied. Highly recommended if you want a casual restaurant sim or Touhou fangame.

Thanks for the fun times!

Edit: Hopefully will get around to playing DLC 2 and 3 again soon (as soon as I relearn the controls lol)

Simple and relaxing game, complimented by the game soundtrack. I love the music in the game. I could listen to it all day and wind down. The gameplay loop is addictive. I find myself wanting to play another in-game day right after the next and eventually find myself playing the whole day. The game has a day and night cycle. During the day, you get to freeroam Gensokyo to gather ingredients, do quest, buy new cooking tools or get to know the Touhou characters. At night, the game becomes a dinner dash type of game where you serve customer's orders. 

The real fun begins when the Touhou characters visit your stall making a vague food request and you'll have to figure out what they want and satisfy their cravings. Feel free to try out different ingredients as their likes and dislikes will be jotted down in the notebook as you unlock them. Satisfy the 2hus and they'll give you a reward spell helping you out or give them stuff they hate and they'll cast a punishment spell getting in the way of your business. 

The game is pretty easy and its hard to mess up unless you deliberately give them food they dislike. I went out of my way to purposely fail story mode just to see what happens and the game was still very forgiving [spoiler] reverting back a few days before and letting you keep all your money and items. [/spoiler] 

TLDR: Chill game with chill soundtrack and cute touhou waifus. Buy it

This Touhou fan game is a great restaurant sim. Although the game mechanics seem simple, there is a surprising amount of strategy in optimizing your progression. the game

I originally bought this game for the collaboration with it and Touhou Blooming Chaos 2, and had just played enough to unlock Mystia. After coming back to the game and actually giving it a good try thanks to a friend, I found one of my favourite relaxing games to play during my free-time.

It's fairly simple, but monotonous at first with a lot of running around until you unlock the Sparrow Song minigame for cooking, which gives one of the best buffs in the game, letting you throw food across the Izakaya right to the customers table, truly a time saver, and lets you serve more guests if combined with the instant eating buff.

Overall from what I've played thus far. The game is incredibly fun, enticing and relaxing once you get into the rhythm of it. The artwork of the main, rare and special characters is absolutely adorable, and the costumes that become available to unlock or purchase if you missed the initial time frame to get them letting you play dress-up with Mystia in a bunch of adorable costumes. The music is equally fantastic and calming, and I've listened to it on repeat while doing some cooking as well just to get in the mood.

If you're a fan of the Touhou series, and want a more relaxed game, I can confidently recommend this game.

Just...get this game. Seriously. It's absolutely incredible! The current price is an absolute steal and on sale it's a no brainer. Also the screenshots show in Japanese, but the game is fully in English too, so don't let that deter you.
To start with, I have never played a Touhou game and have never been into shmups. So I don't know the characters from that series or any other media. If you have any attachment to the series already, you might like this. There's clearly a lot of character history already present from the start of the game, but it doesn't detract from the experience if you're not familiar with it like me.
While a business sim at its core, Touhou Mystia's Izakaya is incredibly charming in its presentation and has a constant flow of interesting and varied content to keep you coming. 20 hours in, I'm still looking forward to the next day to see what happens and what recipes I'll unlock. The characters are varied and interesting. I could list so many details about what makes the game absolutely incredible to play, but frankly you'd be better spending that time purchasing the game right now and finding out for yourself.

Manage a restaurant full of dangerous Japanese folklore creatures, what could go wrong?

That aside, game is fun, good gameplay loop, haven't encountered any bugs, lore accurate enough, so easy that I never lost a game unintentionally.

Touhou ? Check.

Great indie cooking game with amazing OST, pixel art graphics, and atmosphere, simple yet addicting gameplay loop (manage time and ingredients during the day, run your shop during the night), good storyline, and doesnt even need you to know that much about Touhou Project to get the full experience. I was very eager to get into the game, but don't understand the 98% positive rating now.
It's... bland... 
You manage a Izakaya/Small restaurant with guests coming in, ordering a couple drinks and foods with some variety in wishes (you basically just match their wishes with the Tags on each ingredient (Sweet, Low alcohol, etc)) and that's it.
I'm sure at some point it just gets a little more hectic with more tables, more foods and more ingredients and maybe a couple annoying features that just make everything convoluted.

I havn't seen much, but what I saw was the clunky UI, weird keyboard controls and english translations which sound, well, not really native.
For the price it's okay, but I nonetheless was heavily disappointed that the overwhelmingly positive rating apparently stems from an overabundance of Touhou fans just recommending out of love for the franchise.

Edit after the developers response:
Not sure if it's very valid to quantify fans of a franchise by how much they bought a previous title, as there's basically always a certain previous appeal there, like: Is my favorite character present, what is the gameplay, is there music to my liking, etc
With this game there's certainly a ton of characters present, it's a simple gameplay loop, and the music is actually decent.

Nonetheless, I'm more or less overwhelmed by the DLC3 being pointed out there.
It's astonishing that there are already THREE PAID DLCs out and the main game doesn't feel as polished as you'd expect at that point. As said, the UI baaadly needs a rework (it just occured to me that maybe it is just meant to be played with a controller as Mouse+Keyboard just felt horrible), the translations of the main game should definitely be a priority, instead of releasing paid DLC to a half-baked experience for every english-speaking player. The tutorial for the UI was also a huge drag. That Tutorial consists of roughly 70 text blocks, appearing all one after another, explaining every single bit of the UI instead of slowly introducing it throughout gameplay.

To be upfront I have enjoyed my time with Touhou Mystia's Izakaya and I have completed the base game. Of the DLCs I have only finished DLC1.

Gameplay: Touhou Mystia's Izakaya is not a difficult game but it is a bit repetitive so I would recommend pacing yourself. Ingredient spoilage doesn't exist in this game so the only downside to buying more ingredients than you need is that you have less money; Speaking of money, it stops being an object once you get all the upgrades you need (actually shortly before that). The game's difficulty comes mostly from two things menu planning and serving customers, while you can save the former; the latter requires proactive cooking which (to avoid meal spoilage) means you need to understand what each of the customer types will likely order from your menu (a poorly planned menu may mean they won't order at all).

Art: The game consistently looks nice and artworks are all pretty.

Story: I liked the story and you get it from three things in the game, story events, bonds, and the Bunbunmaru.

Nitpicks: Salmon steak isn't a meat, Western food doesn't have bamboo in it, and I disliked the alternate outfits (they generally don't fit Mystia and none of them look like something that would be worn while cooking).

DLC1 expands the base game and story, if you enjoyed Mystia's Izakaya then I recommend buying DLC1.

DLC2.5 is only for you if you like the cooking rhythm minigame (if you're using a gamepad you can't rebind the rhythm keys and have to use a keyboard).

TL;DR: If you like the opening then you'll probably enjoy the game.

I'll be very up-front with this. By no means is this a bad game, but it's really not my style. I would have loved the diner-dash kinda game being able to cook and serve foods to many incoming patrons if not for one thing:

Resource Management.

This part put so much more stress on me than was necessary and I didn't initially think about this feature when buying the game so it really gave me whiplash when it came to trying to satisfy the special customers and finding out I didn't have the right drink in stock or the right kind of ingredient to add the flavor they wanted.

The game was simple enough and I saw the appeal immediately with the controls and basic mechanics of cooking and serving. I was all for it at first, but as soon as the game threw several special characters my way and expected me to satisfy them with an ingredient or drink that I didn't have, I wanted to quit. So I did.

It's a great game, has great music and overall design. I just can't deal with this particular mechanic in any way, plus I saw that I was slowly running out of my Lamprey, which every common customer loves to eat. I kept on gathering during the day, but that didn't seem to be enough. Sorry, Mystia. I gotta pass. If you can play the game and handle this resource management better than me, I would recommend it.

If "feeling all warm and fuzzy inside" was a game this one would hit the spot, just like all of Mystia's dishes!

For real, I haven't felt such happy vibes and tranquility in a game in years... The gameplay is repetitive but even then it keeps you wanting to see more, and the game indeed delivers: New recipes, new locations, new characters... The feeling of reaching max bond level with your fav 2hu girl and her giving you a cute outfit is so cute, but then you see how Mystia looks while wearing it at the izakaya and man, she surely looks beautiful in any costume she wears.

On another note: THE MUSIC. I cant stress this enough, THE MUSIC IS BEAUTIFUL. Getting a big order streak only for the music to change and you notice its a remix of iconic Touhou songs... You know the feel of going to the last boss fight and you hear bits of the main theme? Well, exactly like that, but it has mixes of characters themes or even stages themes, and i'll never get tired of it.

The game even has DLCs if you want more, so what are you waiting for? Go buy this game right now and you will spend countless nights simply running your izakaya, no youtube videos in the background, no chatting with people, no distractions, just you, your recipes and awesome Touhou songs to hype you up as you cook.

First, the positives. The game is beautiful. All of the character art, pixel splash screens, and sprites look great. There are lots of cute outfits to put on Mystia. The music is also lovely, though with only one track per overworld zone and three tracks per izakaya location, they get stale after a few cycles. It's a relaxing experience, a good chill game. The singing mini-game also helps this vibe feeling. I found myself rocking my head to tunes every time the game popped up. The Touhou characters are represented adorably, but they are definitely their 'fanon' incarnations. The dialogue can be a little stale at times, but it's endearing nonetheless. The game has an extremely strong first impression...

... but the negatives become very grating quite early on.

Frankly, this game is extremely repetitive. Once you've served the first few guests, you've served them all. There is no deeper system than what you access in the first two or three hours of the game, and this game has a solid 40-50 hours of gameplay in the base game. It can feel extremely repetitive, collecting the same ingredients in the same couple of zones day after day. There really should have been more special dining events like the final encounter and [spoiler]the Remilia challenge[/spoiler] to add some variety to the daily grind. Speaking of repetitive, the level 3 izakaya has the same interior at all locations. This was a missed opportunity in my opinion. It would be great if there was some way to decorate the interiors of the izakaya beyond [spoiler]the gifts that you are given for reaching max bond level with some of the rare guests[/spoiler] or some way to add some flair to Mystia's house. The basic guests are uninspired. There is very little reason to please them, so despite having a way to increase their satisfaction by tailoring each dish to their species, I ended up just slinging out the basic version of every recipe to them whenever they ordered. They will tip slightly more if they are very satisfied, but money is a non-issue even when splurging day after day. I wish there was some more variety in the basic guests.

It is an extremely easy game with almost no options to increase the challenge. The only way to make the game more difficult is to have no staff member working with you at the izakaya, and this is not that much of a bump. I never once had a guest get impatient and leave. Displeasing rare guests enough to get their punishment cards requires conscious effort. Money is not a problem after the first hour or two of gameplay. [spoiler]There was never a real concern that I would miss one of the game's debt deadlines. I usually made enough to pay Chen back in a night or two, and she gives you a very long time to earn enough to pay her.[/spoiler] I never felt compelled to buy the upgraded cooking tools despite having more than enough money to do so. 

While I enjoyed the rhythm game aspect for the chill factor, it was also a very easy element. I'm an osu! player so that might have something to do with my perception of its difficulty. I never felt challenged by it until I bought DLC 2.5, which in addition to being a separate purchase, is entirely removed from the main gameplay loop. It does expand on the system, but if you play a lot of rhythm games it is easily mastered. It also offers no additional rewards afaik. 

I did enjoy playing the game enough to finish it and get all of the achievements, but I felt that I should leave this review to highlight some of these pain points. The price is low enough that I would recommend at least trying the game out. However, do not expect a significant challenge, a robust narrative, meaningful customization, or anything beyond seeing cute Touhou pixel art and making some questionable onigiri.


Edit: softening some language and mentioning the rhythm game aspect.

Absolutely recommend this game, even if you aren't a Touhou fan at all.

The best way to summarize this is, it's almost like a more chill reimagining of VA-11 Hall-A. It has a similar general theme and gameplay loop, talk to people, serve the correct food items. There is the small gimmick of gathering resources in the daytime, but otherwise, it actually plays a lot like a faster-paced, more laid-back version of the aforementioned.

In terms of its standing as a Touhou game, I feel like this is actually one of the better jumping-off points for newbie Touhou fans. Touhou, as a series, is pretty notoriously hard to get into, with so much overlapping lore and so many characters all doing different things, it's nice to have a game - even a fan game - that can serve as something of an introduction to the series. I don't know if everything in this game is necessarily portrayed as accurately as possible, but it seems to be faithful enough to the original lore that you can get a sense for the characters shown in this game and use that as a base to begin to expand your knowledge on the series in general - I often found myself feeling like booting up one of the mainline Touhou games after I'd had my fill of Izakaya.

The art in this game is gorgeous, and the translation, from what I've seen, is pretty top-notch. Only a few small errors here and there, which is more than impressive for a game translated from Chinese.

While the game isn't difficult by any stretch of the imagination, I hesitate to call it easy, either. A more fitting term for it is casual, because while there is some degree of challenge, and it's more than welcome, the game never tries to really ratchet things up or make things arbitrarily difficult, which suits it quite well.

Going in, I expected a cute, short game, without much depth, about running around in Gensokyo serving food. I instead found a game that inspired me to play more Touhou, and it quickly ended up taking VA-11 Hall-A's place as that game I'd play at the end of the night to wind down. Thoroughly quality experience, whether you're into Touhou or not.

The only things I can really complain about are the sometimes unclear food tags (For example, Japanese/Chinese/Western dishes are an entirely different thing from "Cultural" dishes, and the game doesn't properly convey what will exactly turn your food into dark matter, although the system is easily learned through trial and error, it'd be nice for the game to let you know) and the occasional scarcity of resources.

As for the former, that's really kind of a nitpick, but the latter is something I feel should be at least addressed - After the first two days of playing, I've consistently been dangerously low on lamprey, because they can only be obtained in rivers, from random spawn points, which will sometimes despawn if they move off-screen, and have a random chance of dropping once harvested. Maybe I just have awful luck, but I don't think I've ever had more than ~50 lampreys in my inventory at any given time. It's like this for a couple of specific ingredients, namely, pork and mushrooms, and I'd like to see some other way of reliably obtaining these things, if possible. Even despite this, I don't feel like that problem is in any way something that stopped me from enjoying the game, moreso, it stopped me from experimenting as much as I'd have liked to with certain food combinations.

Overall, I can confidently call Izakaya a hidden gem - If you're looking for a very chill, but very engaging restaurant-type game, this is absolutely worth the money.

This game is quite the treat.

Mystia's Izakaya is a cute management game where you play as Mystia, cook food, all while trying to make enough money to expand your restaurant, open in new places, and pay back ever increasing debts while trying to fulfill your own dream of hosting a concert.

Overall, it's a fun experience. Like many management sims it's relaxing up until you encounter something you don't know how to deal with, but once you get how things work and learn how to manage it it's a very chill game.

The gameplay effectively works on a day cycle; During day you forage and shop for ingredients and drinks, interact with known characters across Touhou to raise your bonds with them, and do side-quests for new recipes and resources. It's worth noting that time only progresses based on your actions, not an actual timer.
During night you run your restaurant. You setup a menu for food, drinks, as well as what cookware you're bringing (certain food needs certain wares, and sometimes you may want to bring extras for something that's popular too cook more). Regular customers come in, you cook, you serve their food. The better and faster you do it, the more tips you get. You can even store extra dishes ahead of time if you expect something to be popular. Plus you get assistants to assist in serving food, drink, or cooking. And then there's the named guests (the actual cast of the games), where they will ask for a specific type of food, and you have to learn their likes, dislikes, etc. to fulfill both their request and their tastes. Doing so well enough gives you extra rewards and improves your bond, doing miserably will hurt your bond and have them punish you. You don't have to necessarily pull from the menu for these rare guests, as you can manually input ingredients, letting you find what works well for each individual guests' likes.
Ultimately, you have to make sure you make enough money by the in-game deadline. As such you have to balance spending, as well as improve your income to make sure you succeed there.

Overall, it's an addicting loop as you try to improve your relationships with everybody, both to gain new recipes and items, but also just to see what happens when everybody starts opening up with eachother.

Story is fun and goofy, artstyle is very gorgeous and adorable, music is fantastic remixes that work very well for the settings. Overall, lots to enjoy~

It's a very wholesome and heartwarming game overall. A great case on time management, but very easy to get into a flow with and not feel overwhelmed by anything beyond insane challenges.

The benchmark of a fan game. Respectful of the source material. The incident Mystia encounters is ridiculous (in the style of the series), but the game itself is well written. Each character has something to say, they don't deviate from their canonical images, and they mention events from the games, manga, and books, which is very cool. The cute art conveys Zun's style well.  The music is beautiful. 

The gameplay consists of two components: during the day the player collects or buys ingredients for dishes, performs tasks, and develops relationships with characters. At night opens his izakaya and cooks for both regular visitors (humans and youkai) and special guests (Touhou Project characters). As time goes on, the conditions will change - there will be new challenges and places to stop the izakaya. All in all it may seem a bit repetitive, which will be true to some extent, but it's still fun. The DLC is almost better than the main game. All the time new scenery, interesting situations in which the player finds himself (especially on bosses)

There are three categories of fan games in franchises: 
1. Mediocre, even for fans.
2. a good game, but only for fans.
3. a good game that may appeal to more than just fans.

So Mystia Izakaya falls into the fourth type: Amazing game for fans and newcomer alike. A great entry into the franchise if you don't want to suffer through Shoot 'em up and you just want to relax.
Got this on a whim. But I was superbly impressed. This is a very good game regardless of whether or not you are a Touhou fan or not..

I recently stumbled upon Touhou Mystia's Izakaya during the Summer Sale, and despite having no familiarity with the developer, publisher, or the world it's based on, I found myself captivated by its charm. As a person born and raised in the United States, the interactions between characters and their thought processes intrigued me, providing a unique and interesting experience.

While the translation may have some occasional oddities, the overall meaning and directions remain clear. The characters in the game are undeniably cute, and the storyline is filled with fun and enjoyment. One aspect that particularly impressed me was the presence of a time limit, which added a sense of urgency, but what I loved even more was the ability to pause at any moment without feeling rushed. This feature allowed me to take my time, consult my in-game book for answers, and effectively freeze time. While some might find this lack of tension frustrating, I personally adored this aspect, as it allowed me to thoroughly enjoy the game without feeling anxious or stressed.

The art in Touhou Mystia's Izakaya is nothing short of magical, and the characters are brimming with charm. The world portrayed in the game is incredibly unique, offering me a glimpse into another culture. Through my interactions with the game, I've not only been entertained but also learned new words and gained an understanding of concepts I hadn't encountered before. Although these insights may not have a significant impact on my day-to-day life, they are still interesting and greatly appreciated.

In conclusion, Touhou Mystia's Izakaya has been a delightful journey for me. Its adorable characters, enjoyable storyline, and the freedom to pause and explore at my own pace have made it a game that I've thoroughly enjoyed restarting to improve my performance. The game's art and cultural elements further enhance its appeal, making it a wonderful experience overall. If you're looking for a game that offers both cuteness and a unique window into another world, I highly recommend giving Touhou Mystia's Izakaya a try.

TL:DR: a well designed and very well priced gem that is sure to be enjoyable to anyone, fan or not of the Touhou series.

GAMEPLAY: 
Totally unlike your typical Touhou shooter game. This one is a slow paced, mostly very easy, resource gathering and cooking simulator. You spend much of the time looking for ingredients and developing relationships with other characters of the game. At night, you cook for customers who visit your place, and eventually you may not even need a lot to do that since you get other characters to help you cook and deliver food to the customers.

Lots of recipes, ingredients, and customer preferences gives quite a bit of variety. That being said, as a resource gathering game with an extensive story and NPC backgrounds, this game may feel grindy at times. Moreover, saves are restricted only after the end of every ingame day.

STORY: 
Very Touhou-like: protagonist must save Gensokyo, this time through the culinary way. A rather different and innovative approach, compared to the shoot and kill gameplay of other games of the Touhou world. Besides Mystia, plenty of other Touhou characters do appear in the game, of course, all of them with their typical stereotypes, such as cheap Reimu or mushroom loving Marisa, both along story lines and gameplay preferences.

GRAPHICS and ARTWORK: 
Pixelated and gives a GBA vibe. Lots of CGs included along the way. Looks very cute, though I would have preferred more "full resolution" CGs and character artwork.

MUSIC: 
Lovely and relaxing, and fits very well with the game style.

SUMMARY:
Excellent and creative Touhou-fan made game with a rather low full price. Cannot recommend enough, especially for resource gathering players and fans of the Touhou series. 9/10

A must play if you like touhou fangames. A cooking simulator that will spare you if you prefer a more casual approach, but will greatly reward you if you choose to give it your all. Beautiful graphics, incredible soundtrack, and fun gameplay with dozens of hours of content.

Also a great find for comletionists, as this game was well over a hundred achievements. Some of them you will get automatically through the story, some you will get just by playing very well, and some you will need to go out of your way to collect them. Aside from a couple (ahem, looking at you, Little Errand Lv. 3 and The Million Pound Note), they are mostly nice and fun.

The only "issue" (kinda) it has is that it can feel a little repetitive after 30ish hours in. But then again that is subjective. But it's definitely not a game I recommend to play for 8 hours straight.

All in all worth every single penny, even if you dont even know "what is a touhou". Dirt cheap and fun to play. Can't recommend it enough

An absolutely chill and wholesome game that keeps you on your feet, one of the best fan game iterations of Touhou Project, centering around our youkai rock stars. If you are a fan of Touhou, this game is a must play, its faithful to the original source as well as the fandom. Even if you aren't a fan of Touhou or unaware, its still a very relaxing game. No danmaku/bullet hell, just a nice restaurant simulator that takes a twist in the spell card mechanic.

The character interactions and dialogue are light-hearted and warm, some funny moments. But the best thing about this game is the soundtrack. Touhou is known for the stage and character themes of the mainline games, the remixing/rehashing of the Touhou OST in this game DOES NOT DISAPPOINT. So much so, I couldn't resist getting the soundtrack bundle from base game to DLC.

Touhou Mystia's Izakaya has grown on me over time, originally I had a do not recommend review, and now I find myself thoroughly enjoying this delightful game. With its undeniable charm and engaging gameplay, it offers a truly pleasant experience. The game's captivating story, accompanied by a cast of unique characters, adds a superb layer of depth, while the mouthwatering food and diverse ingredients further enhance the immersive experience.

One aspect worth noting is the game's affordability, priced at a mere $6. For this modest sum, players are treated to a remarkable journey through the world of Touhou Mystia's Izakaya. The value offered in terms of content and enjoyment far outweighs the price tag.

However, it's important to address a couple of minor gripes. Occasionally, finding effective help for certain missions can be a challenge, particularly the task of providing a food with a cultural tag. Despite unlocking multiple new areas, the recipe needed to complete this mission has eluded me for a significant duration. It would be beneficial to have a clearer progression path or increased accessibility to unlock the required recipe.

Additionally, while the sound sprites initially add to the game's charm, they can become repetitive over time. It would be great to see more variety in the audio department to keep the experience fresh throughout extended play sessions.

Despite these small challenges, Touhou Mystia's Izakaya remains a delightful and worthwhile investment. Its endearing charm, engaging story, and mouthwatering culinary adventures make it a standout game in its genre. For those seeking a relaxing and immersive experience at an affordable price, this game is a must-try.

Whether you're a fan of the Touhou universe or simply enjoy engaging storytelling and delectable virtual cuisine, Touhou Mystia's Izakaya promises to satisfy your cravings. Step into this captivating world and embark on a culinary journey like no other, even if some missions present a touch of challenge along the way.

I really wanted a cute cooking game and I found this on steam. It's super cheap, even cheaper with discount (10 CAD ish) with all the dlc's.
I was playing for three days straight and only progressed a bit, only opened the new areas just now and still have a lvl2 cart with 6 seats.

The game consists of:
1. gathering materials during the day (time management)
2. opening izakaya at night and serve customers.
3. special events with other touhou characters, cute stories, likable even for ppl who don't know touhou (me)

The special elements for cooking:
1. usual customers they order from menu
2. food, drinks and ingredients have properties (like raw, meat, strange, sweet, salty, etc)
3. rare customers only give you hint of what they like. you need to come up with the dish with properties that they like to lvl up the relationship, but after figuring out their fav dish, you can just make that every time they come.
4. there's music game during cooking where you click based on the beat, it gives you special skills like throwing dish at customer table. (I need to figure out how to choose tables to throw at)

so far really love the art and stories and how fast I can make money without trying too hard. It's super addictive.

Tough parts that I'm struggling rn:
1. I haven't figure out a specific recipe for each rare customer ( there's more special customer, not sure if they're in the free version or in dlc), therefore I need to check the customer's likings (dish and drink) and food's properties for every special customer so it's very tiring. I think once I figure out, I'll just brainlessly make those for them and I'll be good. Or I can use those dishes as my menu so I don't need to manually make the food, and just click the dish and it'll autofill the ingredients.
I'm also greedy that I want to sell the most expensive food, so trying to do that while satisfying rare customer needs is harder. So I might just not do that.
2. More areas open up and I'm unsure how to best use my time when I want to go to all areas and talk to everyone and collect every resource XD
3. If you make stuff ppl really like, they'll be really happy. (eg. add meat in every dish you sell to the usual customer that likes it) but it's a lot of work. I might just do it as simply as possible and see if i still make profit.


That's all for now. Let me know what you think of the game, if you're interested in playing as well!

Don't really know much about the Touhou series other than a couple characters and some of the music, but I'd recommend this game even if you don't.

The basic premise seems to be a fantasy world where humans and different types of monsters live.  Some humans and all monsters appear to have some sort of special ability they can use.  The main character is a sparrow monster that runs a little food cart in the mountains with one of her friends.  The game starts with them both opening a restaurant and a particularly angry ghost shows up, demands a bunch of food all at once, and then trashes the place after getting impatient.  Time then goes back a few months to when you're just running your food cart in the mountains.  You get roped into taking on several debts and start running your izakaya



The gameplay consists of day and night phases.  During the day you can buy ingredients, forage for ingredients in each location, or talk to the inhabitants of the area.  Some inhabitants will have quests for you to do for them, others are what are called "rare guests".  These people have a friendship level and at each milestone will teach you a new recipe and a request to serve that recipe to them.  Talking to them once a day increases friendship, but the best way to raise friendship is during the night phase when your restaurant is open.  Maxing out friendship levels can get you some nice benefits, so it can be worth it to hang around an old area til you finish making friends with everyone before moving on to the next one.  One of the first rare guests you meet will also upgrade your Izakaya so that you can have more guests and cooking space.  Another shopkeeper you meet later on can upgrade your cooking equipment.

During the night phase, you choose workers to help you.  You'll only really have one at the start, but you'll get more as you get further into the game.  You can also choose to work alone, as helpers take a small cut of each night's pay as well.  Each helper can be set to serve drinks, serve meals, or help cook.  You can have up to three helping out and can put every single one on serve drinks if you really want to.

When you open your izakaya each night, you pick a menu for guests to choose from.  You can put a set amount of meals and a set amount of drinks.  Then you pick your cooking equipment for the night as well.  The basic food cart can't hold every type, so you'll want to make sure your menu isn't too diverse at first.  Once you've finished your setup, the izakaya opens and customers can start showing up.  Each customer has a preference for type of food they like so they'll tend to order that food more often than others, but they'll always pick something from your set menu.  They are pretty simple to deal with, you pick the menu item and drink they want and serve it to them before they run out of patience.  The game is very generous on customer patience, and I've never seen it even reach halfway on the meter.

The more complex orders come from the rare guests that live in each region.  Rare guests don't really know what food or drink they want, they just want something with a specific taste.  They have a variety of flavors they like, but will only ever tell you one of them at a time.  This is where you start to customize your cooking.  Every single ingredient you have can be added to a menu item.  The most basic food item rice ball just consists of seaweed(Where she gets the rice from, who knows).  That leaves 4 slots of ingredients open for customization.  Riceballs are vegetarian, cheap, and taste like homecooking.  One of the characters, Reimu, loves these flavors, but if she requests something sweet for example, the plain riceball is going to be good for her, but it won't get the best rating since it doesn't have what she requested.  So I can make a riceball, and with one of the four other ingredient slots I can add honey to make the riceball also taste sweet.  Getting the best food rating on rare guests comes with a bonus.  They will use their own special power to provide a buff for you for a time.  For example the first few rare guests will give you random meat items, random fish items, or increase the likelihood of guests appearing for a time.  Likewise, giving a rare guest a dish that they absolutely hate will have them use their power to punish you.  Scaring away guests, restricting your cooking ability, or simply stealing ingredients from your pantry.

After a set time, the shop will close for the night and show you a tally of everything you've sold and the money you made for the day.

Now your character also can buff themselves while cooking too.  For the first couple days you'll have fairly basic operations, but eventually your character will start to sing while cooking as well.  This takes the form of a very small rythm minigame that provides notes on beat with the music of the area.  These are very simple and are actually very generous.  Sometimes you won't even see a note pop up.  Each time you sing while cooking you can buff yourself.  These can come in the form of unlimited patience for guests for a time.  Guests finishing meals immediately.  And the ability to throw food and drinks to a table without having to walk to them.  If you have all three buffs, they combine into a super buff called hyper mode and reset the buff timer to full.  In hyper mode, you no longer get the rythm minigame, and certain cooking utensils actually have special functions while you're in it.

Daily restaurant openings are actually fairly simple and relaxing compared to most other cooking games.  However there is a story in the game that pushes you to certain challenges.  There's a time limit to pay off your weekly debt until you get to the last part of the main story.  Once you get to the end of the main story, it halts until you decide to take on the final challenge.  And while I've mentioned the game is fairly simple and relaxing, this final challenge is an actual challenge and becomes quite hectic.  You get minichallenges throughout the main story that give you an idea of what it will be like, but they aren't quite the same as the real thing.  And while I enjoy the basic gameplay loop, I really like the challenge that came with this and the end of each of the DLCs.

The game's artstyle works well for it, nothing really seemed incongruent when I played and there definitely seems like some good care went into making the environments.  The music, like the bits of touhou music I've heard before, is very good and gives each area its own unique feel to it.  In particular the final challenge music while sounding somber and dire really fit well in its context in the game.

The story was easy to follow, even without knowing who these chars were, the game did well in explaining in the world and each characters place in it.  It did well in selling the main story beat of a conflict that only a master chef could resolve.

Definitely recommend this game if it sounds at all interesting to you.  Its fairly cheap.  I got 100 hours total from the base game and the three DLCs that were out at the time of this review.  There is a fourth one on the way that I will probably pick up when it gets translated.  If you like the base game, each of the DLCs adds 2 new zones with 3 rare guests each and a challenge at the end similar to the end of the base game.  Each of the challenges work well with altering what you know about how the game works.  They all felt pretty fun with DLC3 in particular giving you a challenge for those that want more on the rythm minigame side of things, though it also adds a cool new cooking challenge too where you get to play as other characters that have their own set of buffs different from Mystia's.

Arguably the best Touhou fangame out there, or at least in the running in what is a very fierce competition. Even factoring out the gameplay, if you just like seeing some of your favorite characters interacting with one another in ways beyond out-styling each other with spellcards, this is packed full of characterization that hits right. You're near constantly getting new friends to buy things from you, new friends to find things for you, new friends to give things to you. And it never feels like one-sided exchanges because they write Mystia as a far too wholesome protagonist for a game that starts with a threat of broken kneecaps.

Base Game is a wholesome fun story that also has high stakes, and has my fullest recommendation.
DLC1 feels like a proper 'extra stage', complete with its own boss, and has my fullest recommendation.
DLC2 feels more disconnected and is the weakest entry, but it has Parsee and Yamame, so it has my fullest recommendation.
DLC3 feels like a victory lap, and is the best part of the entire game, and has my fullest recommendation.

Buy it. Buy the soundtracks too while you're at it. It's all great.

I originally wrote a review for this game but it wasn't nearly enough to do this game justice so I'm rewriting it.

Even though I don't have many hours in this game it's become one of my favorite games of all time as well as one of the only games I come back to consistently. Since you probably haven't played the game I'll use a simpler explanation. So, imagine animal crossing but you're in a shit ton of debt and run a restaurant. One of the best parts of this game is probably the atmosphere, the world and the characters are all so charming and the game just gives off a homey feeling overall. One thing that definitely helps with this is the soundtrack, the cheery and relaxing soundtrack of this game is a complete masterpiece, especially during the night segment. Go take a listen they have it in some of the videos on the store page its complete fire. Anyways go buy the game trust me if you don't like it contact me and I'll write you a handwritten apology or somthin go buy game.

TLDR: go buy game, game fun.

This game is amazing. I waited for the English update and it was so worth it. The game has a story all throughout and the pacing is amazing. The game always throws the unexpected at you making you want to play for another day. It continuously gives you something to strive in a way that isn't boring at all. The characters are unique. You have to actually think to play, it's very much not a clicker game. The game gives you tools that you can use in a meaningful way that makes the playing experience more worth while. I downloaded this game yesterday and I have 15 hours already. I should've been doing my homework but this game is just that fun. If you're a cozy gamer but you're tired of the boredom this is the game for you. If you're a foodie this is the game for you. If you want a game that you can play for hours on end this is for you. The game gives you so much freedom in opening your restaurant and it doesn't give you everything all at once. Highly HIGHLY recommend.

「蟲の知らせ」「昆虫のお知らせ」？

5. Some Japanese feel unnatural but most of them are fine.

A cute and wholesome Touhou fan game. There's a surprisingly fair bit of world exploration and interaction with famous Touhou characters.

You gather ingredients, explore Gensokoyo and interact with characters during the day, accepting quests and so on. Actions taken during this phase can impact your business later at night.

At night, you manage an Izakaya (a mobile stall restaurant that serves tasty snacks, meals and drinks), much like a restaurant game sim. You can hire other Touhou characters to help serve drinks and food but never both, so you always have to proactive somewhere in the game unless you hire a full team. Many Touhou characters will appear as special guests with unique tastes that you have to accommodate personally for. If you don't have a dish that quiet fits their needs, you can add extra ingredients to make it more palpable to their taste buds. Satisfy the special guest, and they shower you with rewarding spell cards. Disappoint them, and they punish you with negative spell cards!

It's a surprisingly complex and fun for an indie game, defo worth a purchase; 100% buy it on sale if you're a Touhou fan.

The only negatives are getting used to controls aren't really explained well; esp the rhythm mini-game parts. Minor dialogue typos and errors, and word wrapping when using English on some menus (such as the save menu). The game also saves day-to-day, so you have to see through a full day to play. Also no load menu at the title screen; so you have to pay attention to what save file you are actually using to not cause accidental overwrites!

Super cute cooking management game with some music mixed in. You run around collecting ingredients for the nights opening at the restaurant to cook meals for the guests. Combine ingredients that the guests like for better pay, especially with the rare guests. The story is cute and the music games are nice. They do seem a little on the simplistic side but it is still nice none the least. The controls are a little odd, but that's only because I have never played a game where "j" is your action button. I am used to games where it is "e", "f", space, or enter. But you are able to change the controls to your liking so it isn't that big of an issue. 

The only issue I've had with the game is when you collect something or complete and quest or achieve something in the game in pops up rather large on the bottom left of the screen. Even when you are in the middle of dialogue it is on your screen above the chat bubble. You have to wait for it to go away before you can continue reading. I think this is a translation issue in the game because if it was in the original language it wouldn't be covering the chat boxes, something none the less I wish they would fix.
