From the charming characters and art style, to the funny story, or maybe it's just the fact that it's Touhou.

Unlike a lot of other Touhou games this one really plays on getting the know the characters. Your journal is vital and pulling it up will pause the game so you can take your time to read, the more you learn about anybody, the more notes on said person will be added to the game. 

There are the general mob NPC's who are just the filler but also all have there likes and wants as a group.
Then there are the main Touhou cast along with some guest characters, these are the vip's and they will only give you a veg sense of what they want, so getting to know them is vital, and that's when your journal comes in! Preform Well and they will use a spell card that gives you a bonus! Neutral, and nothing really happens. Upset them and your given a penalty which can really throw you off your game.

Overall the games just straight up fun! Despite being so simple it's simply one of the best touhou fan games out there. And I wouldn't really have it any other way!

An extremely addictive game-play loop that fails to get old. Really cute, really fun and learning new techniques to get the most money or please the most customers is truly rewarding. 

Pros:
- Addictive game-play loop. 

- The game offers a lax tutorial without telling you too much, only keeping the basics. This allows you to experiment and figure out new parts everyday, keeping the experience fresh and enjoyable!

- Cute story. Personally, I have not followed along too hard but its just silly fun!

- Bonding with the rare characters is simple and strays away from complex systems. I like this simple approach more since some games with a very complex bonding system makes it too tedious and annoying for me. 

Cons:
- Not many hints, forcing you to go through trial and error. Which I think is more of a good thing, I enjoy this process of figuring out how maximize my profits, but I know some people will not like this.

- Extremely simple rhythm game mechanics. Clearly or unclearly, this is not a rhythm focused game and the tiny "rhythm" aspect is a simple and cute addition. If you are here for a new rhythm game, this ain't it for you chief. 

- Too easy. Sometimes the game can feel a little easy or simple, especially once you get to the higher levels when it should feel more difficult. That said, this is a more relaxed game and it should not stress you out, but you will never completely deplete a customers patience level. I personally wish there was a hyper or hard mode where failure is more common and punishing.

This is simple and cute, pixel game that combines simple but intricate cooking mechanics with management and ownership of a restaurant with Touhou characters. It starts out simple but evolves into something more intricate as you collect ingredients that you can later use for more elaborate dishes. These lead up to finding the right mix to serve rare guests whom will buff your restaurant for additional revenue. In addition you can interact with guests while not running the restaurant, to learn more about them and even get new recipes or services they can provide. Overall it is a very chill game with great Touhou music and a lots of wacky dishes you can make.

GAMEPLAY

The game has two different modes in one "day". On the first half of everyday, Mystia (the owner) have 16 actions (30 minute time slots from 10:00 to 18:00) to explore the world. These include farming resources on the overworld, buying more resources (this doesn't use up time) or interacting with folks. The goal is to prepare yourself for the night and as you advance the plot, you get a lot more options between what to serve, what to collect and who you want to interact.

The better part of the game is the cooking side where you serve customers. For the usual regulars, they will order off the menu but for any rare guest (the named characters from Touhou), you will have fun combining ingredients to make exactly what they want. As you continue to do so, Mystia records notes so you can start serving wacky but desired combinations to hit all their needs such as salad with honey and cicada shells to Cirno since she like strange, sweet and cool in a food. These lead to better ratings and ultimate for rare guests to their spell card to help your business. There's also a music mini game you unlock early on to tap to the beat to provides a buff to improve your restaurant when you cook. This is fitting for Mystia, a bird youkai who sings and cooks. This adds a nice touch and nod to the Touhou series for its very strong soundtracks.

While each part isn't unique, the game has a very smooth flow and connection between both sides and makes for a harmonious experience. Like the dish and drink you serve together, its a strong pairing. 8/10

GRAPHICS

I'm a personal fan of pixel art and love all the CG scenes and art of each of the characters. They are simple but provide a lot of detail. The main issue I have is that Mystia has a lot of different outfits you can unlock but during story plots, she always wears her default one while her overworld sprite does not match that. This doesn't impact all other conversations but is an odd disconnect to everything else that fits.
9/10

MUSIC

This is Touhou's strength so it is no surprise that these are amazing. They're more on the simpler side with their tunes but fits with the games more calm, peaceful gameplay. What is nice is that the songs do change as you get to the second half to the cooking game as more customers show up closer to closing.  In addition, you can support the artists by buying the tracks as they are available as DLC. 10/10

STORY

The story is something out of Touhou, that is to said it's another "incident" where something bad happens and it is up to the main character, Mystia rather than the usual Reimu or Marisa, to solve it. If you know the series, its no surprise who is the final boss but there aren't much unique twists and turns along the way. The transition to later regions works but doesn't add anything new for anyone who has played or know the series. For those that don't know, I feel you may be lost at times as most Touhou games assume you're aware of the characters in some form and their personality and traits. That said, the game does teach the player about the characters and their basic traits at the end of it so all is not lost. 6/10

REPLAYABILITY

I actually don't mind playing all the DLCs even though the core game is the same and the main differences are the ingredients and dishes. There isn't a lot added if you play the game from the start again as the same dishes will mostly satisfy the same guests (normal or rare). The only randomness is who shows up and thus the order of the spell cards. There is also a bit of randomness when farming on the overworld and what rare ingredients may show up in the store. Even so I don't mind playing since it is a very chill game where one just cooks and experiments with dishes. 7/10

SUMMARY

While not the strongest game, its a very fun, peaceful game where Mystia cooks every night to serve guests from different parts of Gensokyo (the setting of Touhou). If you're a fan of the series, you'll fit right in from the music to the lore of the game and even the wacky dishes. If not, there's still quite a lot of enjoy from the music and really the large forte of dishes you can make and serve to guests. It is not the most engaging or demanding (until you get a rush of guests) but not every game has to be for it to be enjoyable. 43/50

This fan-game is one of the must-gets for Touhou fans, though I hear that there's a sector of Diner Dash fans that enjoy this game as well? Whatever the case may be, the gameplay loop is one of the best I've experienced, the atmosphere is that perfect mix of "it feels super comfy, but you can tell the chef is panicking in the back of the kitchen". 

I do lament that the partner system didn't gel with me. Being vague-ish, Yellow is an active hindrance and I never felt like I used Red if I was doing my job. As well, cash started to lose meaning entirely once I was able to buy out every vendor and still profit in a day on average, so you'll miss your debt to reign in your spending habits soon enough. However, Those are minor gripes about a game with addicting gameplay, comfy music that saves the experience from feeling stressful (most of the time), excellent dialogue, absolutely adorable pixel art, and nods to canon all over the place. (Though, I didn't expect a certain character to show up, given her canonicity?!) 

If you're someone who loved Diner Dash and can handle a bit of weeb, or are an avid touhou fan looking for fangames to play, Buy this game and the DLCs.

A strangely addictive little game.

It has more depth than expected with adding ingredients serving as another way to fulfil the orders without having the 'correct' recipe and many was of serving the special/rare customers. It's definitely worth it for this gameplay loop. Collect ingredients and recipies by day, play a really fun little minigame in the evening.

The art and music are both amazing, in particular the larger scenes - pixel art at it's most gorgeous. 
The music is full of great bops - so much so I've decided to buy the entire OST as well.

The only thing I don't much care for is the amount of dialogue - there's just a lot of really vapid, vacuous back and forth between characters reiterating things they already said dozen of times before (usually really one-note jokes about 'bird brain' main character which, while funny the first time, did not become any funnier after the 20th). I do admit, though, that it might be because I don't really know anything about Touhou - I really didn't care for most of the characters besides maybe Mystia herself, who did have some few chuckle-worthy lines (like the joke about the cost of the new izakaya being higher and higher despite it being the same cart every time).

The story is pretty surface level but it does keep the story going at a nice pace. At the very end, the game basically allows you to complete all the dlc before choosing to go into the final fight, which is nice.

The dlc add more areas, which have fantastic music, and more characters whom honestly feel mostly forgettable (again I'm sure being a fan of the Touhou would change this, but their in-game stories and presentation is nothing special whatsoever). I would say all the dlc is worth the price, however, because of the music, ambience of the izakaya in these areas, the new recipes and, in case of dlc 2 and 3 - the challenges that become available once you hit lvl 5 with all the introduced bond-characters. 

Dlc 2.5 introduces a fun little rhythm game to be played at any map through interaction with a jukebox - which is quite delightful. It's honestly a great timewaster.

Overall, other than the fact I felt obliged to skip most of the dialogue, I'd say this game was absolutely a delight - music was amazing, art was appealing, gameplay loop is incredibly satisfying. Worth the price even outside of sale, all dlc and even the osts included.

Makes me want to leave at the end of shift, at least we don't need to do flips during service time. Could use more music. Controls take some time to get used to as well (Mouse keyboard) better on controller for sure.

An excellent and adorable game. If you liked the "Papas" series of flash games, then you'll love the core gameplay loop of this game - rapidly taking orders and trying desperately to stay afloat after being thrust into running a shop by probably-malevolent forces beyond your control. The only difference is this time it's a catgirl, not a bizarrely moustached man.

I only wish that this game had a mixing drinks system, because for all of the complexities of the foods, you just pick up a pile of drinks, most of which are outclassed. I get a feeling it's too late to add such a thing, but a bartending minigame would be hilarious.

Oh! And if you're worried about not getting achievements - this game has a weird validation thing where it only checks for completed achievements upon booting up the game. After a long play session, quit to desktop then re-boot it, you'll get a big slew of achievements all at once. It'll save you some headache in the long run.

I really enjoyed playing this game. It has moments where it can be challenging, but more often then not it's a pretty relaxing game.
If you played Diner Dash some years ago, you most likely would enjoy this game. You harvest your ingredients from their source and use them to make dishes for your customers. 
When you're not running your restaurant you are making friends with people with all sorts of different backgrounds and interest. As you play further into the game you try to learn more about these characters and what their likes and dislikes are. When you reach the max friendship level, they will give you gifts or perks that will help your restaurant as guests place their orders.
Would recommend playing this game if you're looking for something relaxing and not too overwhelming.

A masterpiece among Touhou fangames. Just utterly adorable and comfy beyond belief. The art, the music, the writing, it's all actually pretty great. Light-years better than what I expected it to be, looking at the dirt-cheap price. 
The gameplay loop is quite addictive too, The game is not particularly challenging, but rewards mastery in a snow-balling fashion. There's good amount of variety and complexity, it caters to a few different playstyles and difficulty levels. But the more challenge you take on, the more you can make, and the more you can invest back and make even more. It's that sort of game. Also do prioritize leveling up bond with characters to maximum, they give really sweet rewards, recipes and of course more cute interactions! 
The game is also just great for learning about the Touhou world and characters. I mean, you have to get to know the characters to know what to cook for them! Absolutely recommended!

The ONLY gripe I have with the game is a technical one, it's stuck to 50hz. It may claim whatever 240fps+ framerate but they're all repeat frames, with only an updated cursor. But also, if you don't use a 50/100hz display, you'll have motion judder. If you use a BFI OLED, ULMB LCD or a good-old CRT, you'll find you cannot get clear smooth motion with this game. Especially annoying with the rhythm game DLC, though it's pretty easy to SS regardless. But the motion blur/judder just strains my eyes.

so after 50 hours w/ this game--during which time i've bought a boatload of other games from the spring sale, but keep coming back to this one--i thought it was fair to leave a review of this game. on the base level, it is a fan game from the Touhou Project, cute youkai girls doing cute things. but i'm here to tell you this is perhaps the greatest deal on a game and its DLC i've yet to find. it's great on the Deck and is deceptively harder and more complex than it seems, and its unique gameplay loop that it addicts you to proves to be a new *Recettear* experience in a completely different context. buy this game. what have you got to lose, it's dirt cheap when they throw it on sale and is already rock bottom in price for the experience this game provides.

if you need more, let me tell you a bit about me and my partner. this is relevant, b/c the most we know about Touhou is the "Bad Apple" music video and that there is some pervy stuff out there related to the property, to be honest, i can't believe i found this awesome game randomly in my discovery tab... and since playing it, i get a deluge of pervy games recommended to me. aside from having to bash every pubescent themed porn game that now comes up on my discovery out of existence, it's crazy that getting all of this around $10 so far has been something i've usually poured this much time into something like *Persona* games. it's really a shame the rep this fandom gets in this one specific case, i had to talk my partner into giving this a shot after he blasted through *Recettear* a year ago on my recommendation, and it was a bit of a sell b/c he thought there was gonna be a deluge of pervy shit in this game. so far the only thing besides doll-like girls prancing in cute dresses is a girl providing a pin up on her exposing her leg. still on the creepy meter, but it's Japanese; we'll take what self discipline the creators are capable of when depicting literal children.

the only other problem i've encountered is that this is a project that requires some heavy translation. that means we have to wait for DLCs that have been out in their native language to get localized. as of this time, the mainline DLCs, numbers 1-3 are available. the other thing i've noticed is that while usually the translation is pretty good, w/ some weirdness and strange turns of phrases aside, but rarely there is some notable bad grammar. bad grammar and a little strangeness still means this game is still absolutely understandable and it has not proven a hurdle to enjoying this game. if this were a game that demanded more money i would be more bothered, but i can't overstate how great of a deal this game is.

the overworld game is a little of a letdown, does look like some RPG maker cash grab. i'm sure it was another reason my partner was skeptical that this is a game worth tens of hours. i've come to believe that the little rough edges on this game actually help. i just quit playing *Harvestella* on the Switch, b/c the framerate is SO BAD it's all i think about while the characters are talking about is that the framerate is a quiet additional character, always making itself known. this game is great on the Deck b/c the overworld isn't the main focus, it's just a means of getting what you need until the next night to open your izakaya. this is a game that begs to have nearly every performance bar tweaked down, making this a game that is absolutely entertaining while being a battery sipper. to boot it runs perfectly on the system, no tweaking required.

it's also a game that knows what its gameplay loop is and doesn't bother you w/ extraneous RPG bullshit. although this game will live or die for you based on if you are entertained by the banter between the girls and the meta story. as someone who is prone to turning cute Japanese stuff off (who the fuck started this rumor that *Fire Emblem: Three Houses* has FUN social link cutscenes??) i really like the strange relationships and personalities these girls have and look forward to finding out what recipes these weirdos have for me. and yes, the main villain of the main game is a mukbanging ghost, totally here for it. 

and now for the meat of the game. like i said, this game has so much going for it for the price point, i'm only just getting to the real draw of this game. the nightly izakaya openings prove to be a surprisingly customizable business experience once you start opening up more. the *Recettear* comparison i made for this game really comes through w/ the fact that you're a girl saddled w/ debt. but where that game featured one big lump of horrible debt incurred by a disappearing papa, this game is driven by both the main character's dreams and ambitions and a villain she slowly becomes aware of that she must learn to be a peerless restaurateur to satiate a bottomless pit of a customer whose hunger is literally world ending awaiting her someday in her future. the gameplay loop is waking each day and you usually get a choice of where to go and what to do. you gather ingredients (try to harvest as much crap off the ground for free to feed scrub customers and get ingredients w/ special tags to make special guests happy enough to rain free gifts and buffs on you) and talk to people to progress your locations, your restaurants, your recipe books, your customer base, your employee pool, your friendships, and your bank account. the game is really not that unforgiving once you figure out how to make money, keep it, AND PAY ATTENTION TO DEBT DUE DATES IN YOUR TASK TAB.

this is just a great game to get into a flow state and let a day's stress melt away. you feel rewarded for getting to know your youkai besties and searching for free stuff off the ground to feed to unsuspecting poors and aristocrats alike. 

i mean, just buy it already.

Good game. Bought expecting something like Recettear and while the gameplay is similar - collect or buy ingredients/items and turn them into pure unadulterated cash via opening a shop - the feel is a bit different.
There is no action gameplay and no dungeons - which is an improvement as those were arguably the least fun portions of that game - the game is also somehow way less comfy than Recettear as each night handling Izakaya is a hectic rush of preparing dishes for 3 - 8 different tables of clients. This can get a bit tiring as there is no option to speed up the process when night is slow or slow it down when there is too much to handle save kicking out the customers which is never good.
It is still rather hard to fail and later on you can get trio of different helpers to make opening the restaurant almost full automatic so in the end the game has weird difficulty curve where it's hardest at the beginning and easiest at the end.
Game is also very pleasing to the senses with its cute graphics and amazing arrangements of ZUN's tracks from mainline Touhou games. It's also fun to chat up various residents of Gensokyo in between tasks thou it sometimes feels like game would benefit a lot from trying to mimic the brief conversation style from mainline games as sometimes a chat between two characters can rival Kojima in levels of length and saying much without saying nothing of substance.
Additionally while playing the game is fun it starts to get grating by the very end especially if you try to grin for perfect ending and/or all of the achievements since doing all of Sakuya's tasks is an exercise in patience. DLC unfortunately doesn't help in keeping the game fresh as it's just doing same things with slightly more ingredients and characters to handle. Personally I think it's reasonable to get the DLC's with Touhou characters you personally like and avoid the rest.
Overall I think this game would score a solid 7/10, bump it to 8 if you are a fan of Touhou Project

Well, I've just started playing this game and I really like it. I can see myself spending quite a few hours on it in the future. The game play is interesting and relaxing and I like the yokai/Japanese culture/Japanese food stall theme.

However, there is a big downside for me. I played for 58 minutes yesterday and did not even get to a point where I was allowed to save the game. There is an in-game dialogue that tells the player that they will only be able to save the game at the end of each game day .... and it says that the developers have no plan to change this and indeed it is too late in the development stage to change it!!!!!!

I really hope the developers implement a better procedure for saving games. The game seems to be aimed at casual gamers, but as things stand, it is just not possible to play the game for the odd half an hour or so. I do not have a lot of free time and I cannot commit to however long I have to play just to be able to save the game.

Premise of the game is collect/buy ingredients, complete quests and then during the night time, earn as much money as possible. I bought the game due to its warm and comfy looking atmosphere, but what I ended up with was the opposite. Ended up having to have the game's wiki open and constantly pausing the game to remember what Tanuki and Neko customers liked aside from meat, taste mechanic the game only slightly hints at.  

 Game starts off with LVL 1 stand, which is comfortable enough to execute the gimmick mini-rhythm game mechanic and deal with constant repeat orders. Once LVL 2 hit though, game because extremely stressful. Limited amount of utilities to cook with and a hoard of customers wanting the same damn thing, regardless of how diversified the menu was. Did it once as it was an event the game coaxes the player into, and never again. LVL 1 becomes slow and boring, LVL 2 is just mayhem. 

I bought the game expecting comfy, as I have several other games that are sweaty and focus intensive, I did not need another game along the same line. Thoroughly disappointed on the pacing of the game, day time exploration is just time management simulator once newer areas open up, as you have to keep tabs on what you have available while trying to fulfill quests, honestly the game does too much for it to be comfortable or fun. Stopped playing all together, would rather be doing runs in Gunfire Reborn, which is honestly less stressful than this game. 

Positive reviews seem to rave about the pixel art and atmosphere. Do not buy this game expecting it to be a fun de-stresser. Just another Touhou bait game.

Extremely cute. This game puts me in the 'just one more chapter' mindset you get when reading a really good book. I couldn't stop playing because each night goes by so quickly. If you like cooking games and cute things, I 1000% recommend this game. It's a little repetitive but the characters and story line make it so worth it.

Almost an hour into the game and I am already feeling more relaxed than I did in a long time.
I will update this review when I am further in, but Mystia's Izakaya seems to hit a soft spot for me.

The characters are cute and engaging, the fetching of ingredients isn't annoying at all and the actual cooking for the guests of Mystia's izakaya is really fun. Also, the progression after a night of serving dishes feels very rewarding.

[b][u]Addendum I:[/u][/b]
My initial eighty minutes playtime have now turned into 6 hours, and the game is still a huge blast! The further you progress with the relationships (side quests) and the main story, the more recipes you unlock to later serve your costumers. Special guests, as well as a rising number of normal costumers you'll have to cook the right meals for, keep the game engaging and challenging.

The game features a time management system. Travelling from one location to another as well as gathering  ingredients each make thirty minutes pass, until the izakaya opens its doors at exactly 6:00pm. At no point does this mechanic make you feel stressed out, because recources are so easy to come by that you will always have enough for the upcoming cooking session. The costumers also have a timer clocking down, but at my stage of progression it is almost impossible to let it run out without actively ideling around for a large amount of time. The deadline of the first main quest makes it seem like it won't be easy to collect enough [spoiler]money[/spoiler] to [spoiler]pay of your [b]first[/b] debt[/spoiler], but shortly before the due date [spoiler]your pay is increased[/spoiler]. 
So while time is a somewhat important factor to plan your day around accordingly, it has yet to become bothersome or even restricting.

I can't recommend it enough, though admittedly the gameplay loop isn't going to be for everyone. Gameplay is like a hybrid of Recettear and Diner Dash with more of an emphasis on building relationships with character. The pixel art is immensely charming, the music is excellent, and the translation is generally pretty good (there are a few hiccups here and there- especially in regards to somewhat stilted English- but if you're familiar with Asian games it's nothing new).

My only real complaint is that the game feels too easy. Compared to Recettear, money is far too easy to come by and repaying the loans your growing business requires was never something I had to worry about. I also found the final boss to be a bit too straightforward and simple. In general, I think rare guests would have benefited from some sort of "novelty" mechanic, so you can't just feed them the same dish three or four times.

That aside, if you're a Touhou fan, this is among the very best of fan games. Even if you're not, if you enjoy games built around economics and running a small business, this is the game for you. At its current price, even with all the DLC it's an absolute steal.

I have a confession to make… I cannot git gud at touhou. Yes, I know, I’m a fake 2hu fan, baka baka easy mode and stuff. I am not a fan of bullet hells and am too dumb to play them… that’s why I’m grateful for this game.
Even if you have basically no idea about the setting of touhou, this cute game will be a great introduction. You play as a birb brained dummy called Mistya. She’s a sparrow youkai, who spends her time frying lampreys and singing… well, apparently in the main games its kinda more sinister with hypnotizing people using nonsense music and scamming them but lets put that away for a while… Ekhm, anyway, you have a chill life of gathering ingredients, learning new recipes, making frens and selling your cookery. Soon however, you are forced into debt due to some totally not contrived circumstances planned by someone who lurks behind the scenes. The debt mechanic pushes the story forward, as well as pushing you to constantly improve.
The game is split into two phases – day and night.
During the day you collect ingredients, talk with people and solve most quests. You can also pre-cook some meals for the night but it can be risky – any cooked meal you don’t sell is wasted and you lose it as well as ingredients that made it. Your friends are all from the cast of touhou games and mythos – a peach growing celestial delinquent, a not-blind girl who keeps running into trees, ZEH JAPANIZU GOBURIN!, an annoying prankster scammer bunny I want to strangle AND MORE. By hanging out, talking with and completing quests of these characters you get various items. Sometimes it’s a costume, sometimes it’s an item with some kind of special effect. Most often however, they are recipes, which are important for game progression. The more recipes you have, the more customer types you can serve and the more money you can squeeze out of them.
The recipes as well as ingredients have their own ‘tags’. For example ‘cool’, ‘vegan’ ‘sweet’ ‘weird’ etc. Each type of customer who visits you at night has different preferences. Even the generic npcs – a bunny youkai will prefer veggies, a snek youkai will like meat and sake… for some reason lol. However, special characters will have harder to understand tastes. That annoying bug girl Wriggle might come and say “Are you one of those weirdos who likes their steak well-done?”. What the hell does it mean? Well, its a small riddle, all special characters have these riddles to make the game just a tad bit harder. In this case wriggle was asking for something with a ‘raw’ tag. However, if instead you gave her a dish with ‘strange’ tag, she’d still like it, just less. That’s because Wriggle likes her dishes raw or strange. Thankfully all likes and dislikes of various guests are written down as soon as Mistya discovers them. You can access her notes at any time so if some request doesn’t make sense you can hopefully figure it out using your notes. If your special clients are satisfied or insulted enough, they give you spell cards. This time, they don’t cause an epileptic shock from looking at a fuckton of flying bullet balls. Instead they do stuff like increasing your profits, calling up new clients, giving you rare ingredients or summoning cute animals that make people give more tips lol.
The punishment spell cards can disable some of your cooking appliances, make you blind for a time, summon insects to scare people away, steal your booze, etc. Best keep your frens satisfied… OR ELSE!
There’s more interesting mechanics at night – you can only put a limited amount of food and drinks on the menu, you get a mini-rhythm game mechanic where you earn bonus buffs(and it dynamically changes depending on the CURRENTLY PLAYING BACKGROUND MUSIC!), you have a helper who can deliver foods or drinks in your place, you get combos that boost your income… but the longer I gush about the game the closer I get to the character limit and I still have a lot to say ;_;
Instead of gathering ingredients one can also buy them or have a friend help gather them. There are many regions though, all with different ingredients and different clients if you decide to open your izakaya there. Most actions in daytime cost time – travelling, cooking, gathering and some interactions with npcs. So you have to plan accordingly. Later on you’ll be able to teleport using money instead of time but by then, money is barely an issue.
Still, there are a few negatives – there’s a lot of recipes and they are pretty weirdly sorted, not all dlcs are translated though that’s understandable for a doujin studio. Some customer riddles are really convoluted and dumb – no idea if they want something ‘aura bursting’ ‘strength boosting’ or just ‘hot’. Some of those tags are also kinda weird – what the hell is ‘aura bursting’? All clients have a limit to their money, but you don’t see it. When wanting to maximize profit or just not sell them something that will bankrupt them and piss them off it’s annoying to not know how much cash they have. Maybe some item or rhythm game boost could let you do that?
Still, it is a massively positive, chill game. A great introduction to touhou for non-fans, a great fan game for fans. A chill restaurant game for casuals or a fast paced serve-em-up for those who want to play it that way. The music is heavenly and the story is cute.

At the same time I could list many aspects of the game, but that alone is not enough to describe the whole existential experience which you will submerge in. It is a strange irony that opposites grow out from each other: the cruel and suffocating worklife in Japan spreading the creation of moe anime; Monolithic, society-kneeling tech companies adopting cartoon mascots and seeming slang; Russia's fascination with projecting violence, but being weak and crippled by addiction. Despite what one may claim, man has a tendency to fulfill the desires it is lacking, unconciously.


    After passing by an aisle the width of Mars' moon phobos full of action shotters, yet more mobile cash, and puzzle optimization puzzles there was a lone game, flanked by all of the aforementioned boring games, and its cover so colorful and pastelized that recognizing the quantity of moe contained within took minutes of eye-adaption. The choice to put it in your hand was imminent and impulsive, though you knew nothing of the journey lying ahead.
TL;DR: This game is super relaxing and cute. If you like memory games and are a causal player, you will like this game. If you like creating spreadsheets and squeezing out extra points, you also get space.

I will have a hard time finding unique ways of saying [i]“unexpectedly positive surprise”[/i] for this review.

Touhou’s intellectual property is known for being a fangame free-for-all since ZUN is surprisingly comfortable with people using setting of Gensokyo and its residents for their own projects. Results of this arrangement can vary in quality, but often times you can encounter a beautiful gems laying on the ground.

While we are definitely talking about valuables right here, Touhou Mystia’s Izakaya punches even higher above that. This title not only should satiate curiosity of the Touhou fans but also deserves to be experienced by much wider audience. Game oozes with great atmosphere and engaging gameplay, despite not looking that much special on paper.

Daytime sections seem to be pointless at the very beginning, but that assumption quickly disappears after you outgrow your starting location. Suddenly, half of the game becomes a little time management puzzle of planning which ingredients to pluck out from nature or which NPC with a sidequest to visit and talk to. Most actions take a chunk of time from your schedule and you want to be sure that your restaurant is stocked with everything you need for a successful night.

Nighttime brings out cooking, customer serving and rhythm minigame in a very arcade-like package. Difficulty isn’t steep, so you can take your time and have a cozy experience. However, if you risk it for the biscuit - trying to feed the most amount of people, in the best way possible - game becomes frantic fun, as orders come, go and leave a positive review sound effects ringing in your ears. Special rare clients also throw an enjoyable wrench into your gears – where you are granted great rewards and status buffs when you interpret their cryptic tastes correctly, but also get punished in funny ways when you serve them a wrong dish by mistake or accident.

Both daytime and nighttime gameplay styles are good on their own, but Mystia’s Izakaya overarching structure hold ups as well. You could argue it can get a little repetitive over time, since each new location you unlock works more or less the same and side quests are very similar to each other. In spite of that, various story events and cute character interactions with surprisingly good writing will keep you occupied and should counteract any familiar bits. Music should keep you great company as well, since most of the arrangements provided are perfect match to the game’s specific tone. Pixel art is also amazing, although one could wish that some objects in the game world could get at least few frames of animation.

The only problems I could point out against the game are various nitpicks and spotty polish in few places.  I do wish there was an optional hard mode difficulty. Some art could be improved a little bit and few lines of dialogue could have their translations corrected. List of possible improvements should be considered long, but its nature only betrays the independent origin of this title and how enjoyable throughout this game is - despite its deficiencies.

Touhou Mystia's Izakaya had no business being this good. For the base price – it is an absolute steal. I wholeheartly recommend trying your luck with grilling some Lampreys and cooking a nice Ramen soup for yourself to enjoy.

-----JOJO MEMES TIME-------
My name is Mystia Lorelei. Running a catering business for 33 days. My hut is in the central section of the youkai trail, where is a pivot to connect all other places in the game, and I am not married. I work as the proprietress for the Mystia's Izakaya , and I got to work every day by 6 PM at the earliest. I don’t smoke, but I occasionally drink. I’m in bed by 12 PM and make sure I get ten hours of sleep, no matter what. After having a glass of warm sparrow sake and jotting my daily life about twenty minutes before going to bed, I usually have no problems sleeping until morning. Just like a baby, I wake up without any fatigue or stress in the morning.

I was told there was a close friend who's deeply indebted. I’m trying to explain that I’m a person who wishes to hold a concert and a bigger Izakaya. I also take care not to trouble my friend into such an awkward situation, like being pushed to pay off the debt or lose one leg, which would cause me to devote my endeavor to larger business to earn more. That is how I treat my friend and dream, and I know that is what brings me happiness. Although, if I were into a spell card fight I wouldn’t lose to anyone.

Very comfy, yet deceptively difficult when you really get going, Touhou Mystia's Izakaya is a really fun and cute little restaurant sim that I wholeheartedly recommend to anybody who enjoys that sort of game! If you're interested, but concerned about not knowing anything about Touhou other than the wide variety of memes, you genuinely don't need to know anything about it to keep up with the plot. Everything you actually need to know to succeed is in the Notebook menu and within the guides in the Steam community. :D Have fun!

As someone who enjoys cooking and restaurant sims, it is rare to see something become a success on steam, either the game has great concepts but falls flat with the same failure rate as the restaurant industry irl or they last long only for mediocre visuals to put a hamper on the gameplay cycle. Either way, the restaurant management genre is remarkably difficult to pull off.

Mystia's Izakaya is one of the few experiences out there that serves as the one star Michelin star of restaurant sims compared to titles like Crossroads Inn, Restaurant Empire, Recipe for Disaster or Chef. Taking place in the popular Touhou Project setting. This game serves a hearty meal that earned it's overwhelmingly positive rating. 

The premise focuses on the one of the members of the weakest Youkai, Mystia Lorelei, most infamous for being devoured by the main antagonist Yuyuko from Perfect Cherry Blossom. After a disastrous dinner service that is about to have her devoured again. Keine saves her and sends her back to several months earlier where she was tasked to saving her friend from debt, little do she know. Her debt goes beyond a mere 3000 yen as the fate of Gensokyo hangs in the balance. The game is a faithful fan game for the Touhou setting, featuring an expanding cast of well known characters such as Marisa, Reimu and Sanae as well as Mystia's fellow yokai Cirno, Wriggle and Rumia. 

Gameplay wise it is similar to Diner dash and Traveller's rest. Being an RPG Maker type game where you goal is to make as much money as possible in a two week limit with side stories and the cast of Touhou serving as both friend and foe to your success in the kitchen. In the daytime, Mystia has to procure ingredients for her dishes at a restaurant by either buying, gathering or asking friends to find stuff to give her. In the evening she runs her Izakaya proper, having to make sure the patrons have something that fits their price range as well as what they want to eat. 

What makes the game stand out is the cooking system is about fulfilling tags, some tags are mutual exclusive (For example, you can have meat or vegetarian, filling or small portion, mild or savory) and others are dishes that are incompatible with the ingredient (Like your signature grilled lampreys) where attempts at culinary creativity may result in a dark matter disaster. It is also through these tags you meet the culinary demands of your toughest food critics, the cast of touhou. As I mentioned earlier, some like Rumia want raw meat while others like Reimu hates food that strips her of what little money she makes from her shrine and demands cheap and filling food. Meeting those tags requires you to build a scaling staircase of satisfied rare dinner guests who offers new recipes. The difficult cycle is mild for a Touhou game, but extra challenges will require you to have decent kitchen equipment, a good store of ingredients and remembering what does guest want. So far I have no problem with the dinner guests save the scripted ones. But the challenge for me is trying to be as creative as possible with themed menus everyday.

The 8bit graphics don't deter the game from being enjoyable as it provides the game with vibrant food art and cg designs and adorable sprite gifs.

If there is only one con of the game it is the fact that algorithim recommended me adult games as a result. I guess when your game is cheap, it also attracts other cheap adult games without the quality that Mystia Izakaya has

Overrall, Mystia's Izakaya is a welcome addition to the Touhou fangame lineup as one of the must plays, and for the price you are paying. It is like that soy chicken joint, it's cheap but delicious and worth a buy.

Mystia's Izakaya is a wholesome cooking weeb game. The game is broken into two main components. During the day it's a relaxing experience where you can wander around the town at your leisure, collecting ingredients, fulfilling quests and talking to the various waifu characters and such. This part is pretty chill, with RPGmaker vibes, cute art and so on.

In the evening, however, you open up your restaurant and the experience descends into chaos as you rush around cooking stuff, preparing food and drinks, serving customers, trying to keep everyone happy and make big money before you close at midnight. 

The flow of the game is really nice, that juxtaposition between the tranquillity of the day and the stress/chaos of the evenings. And the game has a very satisfying progression system where you make money, expand your restaurants, acquire more complicated equipments/recipes/ingredients, and build closer relationships with the other characters. The art, sound, music and quality are all superb.

However, the game is WAY too long. It took me 40 hours to do the main story. Things start to get pretty repetitive after the 20 hour mark. By the last half I had unlimited money and resources and I was just waiting for the game to end, which it does automatically after around 90 in-game day/night cycles. Regardless it's still a really good game, especially given the price.

Touhou Mystia's Izakaya is a cute chibi art style restaurant simulation game. The game is filled with lore & (from what I have played so far) a great story. 
You play in day cycles during the morning/day gathering or buying ingredients, talking to villagers, prepping meals for the restaurant & doing any side missions you might have. Then night time you are running the restaurant serving food to the customers.
The game is designed you progress each day which keeps it at a good pace so you do not plow through levels or progress to quickly. The games pace is cute, fun & relaxing. As you level the restaurant up it can get more challenging adding more tables etc.
The added special customer is fun as you have to cook based off there likes and dislikes. Good food results in a good card, bad results in a bad card which both effect you & your restaurant.
The NPC characters are cute & there dialog is fun. You can gain friendship levels with them. There are more areas to unlock & explore.
It is easy to get lost in the game for hours. For anyone who loves chibi style as well as simulation games this is a must. I am so glad I grabbed it in the sale & can't wait to play more. 
Defo 100% recommend.

cute and addicting

You play as Mystia, owner of an Izakaya who must carefully manage the business so you don't get your kneecaps broken by Chen because of your debt. In the morning you gather/buy ingredients, bond with familiar 2hu characters, and do side quests. By night, you open your Izakaya while making sure the menu and equipment fit the preferences of the customers of the location you open to. 

The Izakaya gameplay is daunting at first, you must memorize customer's orders, keep track of which table ordered what, and ensure customers don't run out of patience. It gets very hectic once you unlock a bigger Izakaya with 8 tables. Unfortunately, the gameplay doesn't really change, after you get used to it, it starts to feel stale and repetitive. After unlocking the fourth location (Scarlet Devil Mansion) I was already feeling a bit burnt out.

That said, I do feel like the game is worth it. Especially for fans of 2hu. You probably shouldn't buy the DLCs before you try main game though.

Seriously, this game is very good; it's a very engaging restaurant simulator with the cute characters created by ZUN presented in a visually pleasing semi-pixelated art style. The mechanics are easy to grasp. The main sources of difficulty are acquiring the ingredients on time (before the working hours of the Izakaya), pleasing the clients, making enough money to pay back the (((Yakumo moneylenders))) and the Yuyuko culinary boss fights later in the game. There is a bit of a puzzle element to the game, as some clients, especially the named Touhou character-clients, prefer some food types over the others; thus Mystia's little notebook is a must read before, during and after every working session. Pleasing those named clients reward extra tips and bonus spell cards, while displeasing them (ignoring their orders, serving disliked food) may result in them leaving or issuing malus spell cards against you. The player should also try to complete the extra tasks given by Gensokyo's characters and the Bunbumaru newspaper before the working hours of the restaurant because their rewards are usually very useful (money, special currency, rare ingredients, friendship points, etc.).

"Touhou Mystia's Izakaya" was originally developed by a Chinese team of Touhou fans. As of the writing of this analysis, most of the game has been translated to English but some untranslated text can be found here and there. I estimate the ratio 90% / 10% translated vis-á-vis untranslated (including the DLCs). I'm certain the developers are working on that, because they are active in the Discussions section and listen to the feedback of the players. This great game only got better. They also included in the game extra characters from collaborations with other Touhou game developers. It's nice to see such solidarity.

Sorry for any grammar or typographical mistake. Thank you for reading this review.

[spoiler]The second wave of the final mission gives you a bunch of bad spellcards. This idea is amazing, and since I rarely got them it was a fantastic challenge.  However Meiling has an ability that breaks a table, and thus removes a guest. I think she actually made it easier as there were fewer punishment cards going off. Unsure what I'd do to fix it. A larger issue was the 3rd wave. Cooking for Yuyuko seemed anti-climatic compared to the prior wave. I quickly found what she enjoyed and kept throwing it at her, It and I didn't feel too creative. I think the ending should require you to cook with a huge variety of tags instead of focusing only on set qualities. Yuyuko could ask for a spicy western, or a legendary strange meal next etc. As you go through if you keep using the same tags she will get bored. Really felt like my large repertoire of recipes was useless here.[/spoiler]

My game of the year is: Mystia's Izakaya. 
While being a Touhou fan game: it's very un-touhou like. 

The only thing that carries over from Touhou is the characters. 
The game-play is like Cooking Mama and Stardew valley mixed together with a hint of animal crossing. 

The main game of cooking for your customers, and friends is simple to understand, but hard to master. There is a surprising amount of depth with how you can mix and match different recipes with ingredients to maximize customer happiness. 
As you progress further this depth is furthered by the introduction of employees and different levels of your Izakaya. 

The game is not hard by any means, but the few boss fights in the game can create a surprising amount of tension when the timer gets close to zero. 

All this backed by an amazing chip-tune soundtrack full of remixes of classic Touhou songs, and original pieces. 
It even has some fully voice acted and sung songs for the intro, and credits. 

All in all: this game has an insane amount of love and care put into it. 
It's truly one of, if not the best Touhou fangame. It stands side by side with Luna nights.
My only complaint would be the lack of side quests after the main story is complete.

It's a good game. As of time of this review, the devs are still updating and releasing new content for it. The devs are also very communicative with the players and have addressed previously reported issues. The price of the game is also extremely cheap for the amount of content the game contains, DLCs included. Whether or not you enjoy the game play is subjective but the quality of the game is good.

I recently had the pleasure of dining at Touhou Mystia's Izakaya and I was blown away by the food and atmosphere. The Izakaya, or Japanese pub, is a cozy and inviting space with traditional decor and a warm ambiance.

The food was absolutely delicious, with a wide variety of dishes to choose from. I started with the edamame, which was perfectly cooked and seasoned, and then moved on to the Takoyaki, which were crispy and full of flavor. For my main course, I ordered the grilled salmon, which was cooked to perfection and served with a delicious teriyaki sauce.

The service at Touhou Mystia's Izakaya was also top-notch, despite the fact that the restaurant was almost destroyed by a crazy diner who was unhappy with their meal. The owner, a young girl named Mystia, managed to calm the situation and even continued to cook and serve customers by herself with the ingredients she had gathered. It was truly impressive to see her determination and dedication to providing a great dining experience.

Overall, I had a wonderful experience at Touhou Mystia's Izakaya and I would highly recommend it to anyone looking for delicious Japanese cuisine in a warm and welcoming atmosphere. The owner, Mystia, is a true gem and her hard work and dedication to her customers is truly admirable. I can't wait to go back and try some of the other dishes on the menu!

Will play again!

[h1]Sell food or lose your legs[/h1]

Beyond excellent restaurant management game and a great entry point to the Touhou "universe" or whatever you call it (it's my first Touhou-related anything but my Touhou friends highly recommended it). Art, graphics and gameplay are all super polished. 

You are Mystia, a timid-but-determined bird-girl (I heard she has a lore justification for running a restaurant involving grilled lamprey). You get into the restaurant business to stop a shyster catgirl from breaking your friend's nico-nico-kneecaps over an unpaid debt. It's one of my favorite intro chapters in gaming.

Each day you gather ingredients and drinks with a limited number of time slots to use. Getting the most and best ingredients feels like a skill you'll never fully master. Then, your preparations come to fruition as you serve fine meals to the unique denizens of Gensokyo, learning their tastes and cashing tips to avoid leg-crippling debt. Actually running the restaurant has a perfect balance between frantic and calm. The max-level izakaya attracts dozens of customers, but time stops when you interact with cooking equipment or your notebook.

The secret sauce in this game is how satisfying it is to play for dozens of hours:

- You slowly befriend a fascinating cast of characters: youkai (monster-people), shrine maidens, onis, and more. Each is fun to talk to and unique. Their spell cards are an excellent opportunity to admire the cute-AF pixel art.

- You gain access to new areas, invest into new locations, and discover new ingredients to satisfy ever more exotic tastes. Mastering the ever-increasing layers of complexity is satisfyingly profitable.

- You'll upgrade your cooking skills and equipment.

- Finally, you help Mystia and Kyouko (the friend and extortion victim mentioned above) achieve their dream of holding an epic concert, and, tbh, that's pretty rad for this pair of cinnamon buns.

A true work passion and love worth thrice the price. Buy this game if you're even remotely interested in cooking games, management games, and cute anime girls.

So I'm fairly new to the Touhou series, I've been aware of the memes, some of the characters, music and art for over a decade now. I only recently started getting into the lore, stories and games (both canon and fanon) but this game is very beginner friendly, whether you know about touhou or not. It helps if you have some cultural experience regarding Japanese culture and mythology (gods, yokai, shrine maidens, etc) to understand more of the terminology.

That said, it's criminal how cheap this game is and how much hours you can dump in. I'm 14 hours in and there's still so much to do. I cannot understate how addictive this is. If you're a fan of cooking/serving sims (I grew up playing Diner Dash as a kid) you will certainly enjoy this. Do not expect the wackiness of Overcooked. This game is very chillax and has helped me calm down a few times. 

 cannot understate that this is truly a hidden gem, whether you are into Touhou or not.

A very addicting casual game that's great for new and old touhou fans.

Tried and true casual restaurant gameplay, like all those papa's pizzaria games but with adorable pixel art touhou girls, "Mystia's Touhouria" if you will. Very satisfying to play and the rare customers system keeps you on your toes and prevents each night of play from getting dull. My monkey brain loves to see the numbers go up

Story plot-wise isn't much to write home about, you're solving another incident but with time with Mystia's cooking. However, the bits of lore, history, and jokes you come across are really what I read the dialogue for. Mystia is particular is so endearing, always being strung along by the other stronger beings, while she's too much of bird-brain so see that she's obviously not the one in control of the whole scenario. 

I also HAVE to mention the artwork in this game. It is beyond precious and anytime a new CG comes up I just have to take a second to admire it, as well as screenshot. Each CG on their own would really be perfect for a desktop BG. The contrast of the soft colors and whimsical atmosphere combined with harsh pixel lines is really something else. Seriously, the game is beyond gorgeous and unlike anything else I've seen. The ONLY complaint I would have to make (and it's very small) is that there's something off to me about the chibi-style overworld sprites, they don't feel quite as polished as everything else you see. Maybe it's the proportions or shape of the faces? It just feels really boxy, but that's just me hunting for something to nitpick about with the art honestly. 

In short: If you like touhou or easygoing casual games, try this out! I've already convinced a couple of my friends to buy this game.

This might very well be my perfect game. I've loved restaurant sims since they were browser games where you had to manage making a milkshake for one customer and cotton candy for another before people got fed up and left. I had hopes a few years ago when Little Dragon Cafe was announced, but when it launched the reviews pointed to a lack of emphasis on the cafe management aspect and my hopes were dashed. And now by chance and the power of the Touhou Project, in comes Mystia the night sparrow and her lamprey stand.

If you don't know Touhou, that's okay. This game has no battles of bullets (unless they're hiding in one of the DLCs), so just accept that the world is full of youkai and no one is human unless the story says so and you'll be alright. The characters are all displayed beautifully, from the first appearance of Mystia rushing to Kyouko's aid to the moment the curse is broken and the subject of your waking nightmare starts to cry about how delicious all the food is. This is one of the few casual sim games to make me cry from emotion, and maybe I'm just a sap, but every time you progress in bond with a character I can feel the emotion in it.

Unlike most sim games, time only passes in this game when you do something that makes it pass. No need to worry if you forgot to pause; as long as you don't change maps or go hunting for resources you'll be fine. Oh--or you stop to invite someone to the izakaya, which was how I used up most of my time once I started forming bonds and unlocking that option.

Money in the game is also not really a problem. It's a resource, but as long as you read the tags for special customers and keep stocked up on popular drinks, you'll only need to choose between a bit more shopping and a higher-commission partner for the evening. I never worried about scrounging for money. At one point I realized I'd been overshopping and only had two days left to pay the debt. I did it anyway. It makes the game feel relaxing rather than stressful to know that money is cheap.

Your real resources in the game are ingredients. I've lamented not having the time to cover all the shops in all the DLC maps in one in-game day, much less all the gathering points. I spent more than one trip just hitting CTRL ("buy all of it") at every vendor I could get to, because I could get money more easily than I could get those five more cuts of pork. But being able to twist in whatever flavors I wanted, and see pink dialogue and reward spell cards pop up from every special customer, made it worth it.

Objectively, even I have to admit the game isn't perfect. For some reason although Steam says that my cloud status is up to date, I've been missing my most recent save each time I change computers. I'd also like to see the system of filtering recipes improved; tags aren't alphabetical and sometimes I've had to go a circuitous route to get the keyboard controls to select a tag at all. An option to sort more or save recipes as favorites of special customers would be nice too. But that's objective. Subjectively, none of those things makes me love the game any less. Aside from having to decide where to pick up the game again, it doesn't make me want to play any less. So while I could point to some flaws and areas I'd like to see improved, I still stand by this being my perfect game. 10/10

[h1]You gather, you cook, you sing.[/h1]
[i]Literally an anime-style of [url= https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.glu.dashtown&hl=en&gl=US]Diner Dash[/url] with a touch of [url= https://store.steampowered.com/app/413150/Stardew_Valley/]Stardew Valley[/url] and [url= https://store.steampowered.com/app/70400/Recettear_An_Item_Shops_Tale/]Recettear[/url][/i]

[i]Touhou Mystia's Izakaya[/i] is a deep cooking and light business management kind of RPG game. You will be playing as Mystia Lorelei, a night sparrow-youkai, a Japanese folklore demon, intent on running an Izakaya, a Japanese street food and alcohol stand serving humans, youkai, fairies and spirits alike in order to clear debts and to hold a concert. YES, A CONCERT IS A BIG DEAL FOR OUR SPARROW OVER HERE!!!

In the game as you roaming in the beautiful land of Gensokyo during the day, you will be expected to do some foraging ingredients [spoiler](give me a déjà vu of Stardew Valley and Harvest Moon)[/spoiler]. As the night comes, you will be planning your food and drinks menu based on the amount of ingredients you have in your inventory and open your stall. You will be cooking up meals, dashing here and there to serve the foods and drinks to your customers on time.

There is also a mini rhythm game while you cook - where it allows you to gain various of buffs that could help manage your stall better on that night itself. The cooking system also provides lots of personal touches and experimentation so that you could create the perfect meal to satisfy your customers’ taste preferences especially the rare and special guests. There are also times where the news will inform you regarding the current popular or unpopular food trends – which is very helpful when you are considering what menu to offer for the night.

In term of character development, I find each of the characters so full of personality and with their own individualistic storylines. This plays out while you are roaming and communicating with them during the day or when they drop by your stall to dine in your food during the night. This leads on to a very profound and gratifying relationship system that allow you to gain new recipes and ingredients to various buffs when you feed them the right dish at the right time.

Overall, it is an incredibly relaxing and enjoyable game. I absolutely adore how stunning the pixel visual art is as they are so lively and vibrant in their expression and personalities. The music and soundtracks are fitting accompaniment to the game. Everything from the mechanics and music to the artwork harmonizing together so well to create a captivating and absorbing gameplay experience. [b]I highly recommend this gem, absolutely worth every penny.[/b]


[h1]Do I necessarily need to know Touhou in order to play this? - No, you don’t.[/h1]

If you do not know what Touhou is, that's okay. You can still play this game and I guarantee you will still love this game a lot. But if you are a fan of Touhou, then welcome home to Gensokyo that we love so much!! The music, the characters and the world, you are surely going to love every bit of it.

The game is pretty fun. With the release of the English translation, I was able to try it recently. There are a lot of great aspects to the game, so I will start with them:
-The art style is great. This was one of the selling points of the game for me. It is pretty unique and cute, it fits the game perfectly. The character designs from the original Touhou series transfer over to this art style nicely.
-The gameplay is fun. It is easy to understand and enjoy. Preparation phase, consisting of collecting resources, as well as befriending the many different NPCs the game has. If you preform certain actions, time will progress until it hits a certain time. Then serving dishes to customers, accumulating combo and earning funds to meet certain objectives. The funds earned depend on the dishes and drink value served. You earn many dishes as you progress through the game. With the introduction of many different areas and styles, it adds a bit of variety to the experience. I was always looking forward to what was in store when moving to another area. 
-The mechanics are well done. There is a bit of complexity to the game, with the addition of rare customers, these are NPCs you may befriend when exploring the areas during the preparation time. They will ask for dishes that fill out certain tags. Giving them dishes that make them happy will give spell card bonuses based on the character and also raises their friendship. Giving them dishes they hate will give debuffs on the other hand. This is interesting and there are lots of shenanigans you can pull with the bonuses to earn extra funds. It adds a nice element of strategy to the game. The story missions are creative with the restrictions the game's mechanics in mind, they are challenging, but enjoyable. 
The kizuna system is nice too. As you progress, you can befriend many different NPCs on the way. Raising friendship through means like talking to them during preparation phase or giving them great food in serving phase. As you raise the friendship, you earn many different dishes that help expand your arsenal. These dishes are great, they can be used for the many quests or make it easier to satisfy the rare NPCs. As you raise the friendship higher, you can earn certain permanent benefits, cosmetics or more quality of life or features. I love these rewards and they add a lot of incentive to befriend the NPCs.

  There are a few nitpicks,  or things that I would like to point out. This section may contain spoilers near the end so please be cautious. I will try to tag them if possible. 
-There are a few UI bugs, or scenarios where certain lines are not translated outside of the DLC, but I assume they will be fixed eventually. They don't really take away much from the experience thankfully
-The English translation is not the best, but it is understandable. I understand that learning a language is hard, but I thought it actually added some charm to the dialogue and leads to some funny lines. I'm looking forward to the translation of the DLCs too. 
-The progression can be predictable or repetitive at times, from a critical standpoint. The areas follow the same format of 3 NPCs, collect resources from the area and certain recipes from certain NPCs to upgrade your izakaya. The gameplay is still enjoyable and relaxing, but it is something I have to point out. 
-There are some weird RNG or luck elements, for example [spoiler]There is a collaboration NPC during the human village izakaya that will ask for western cuisine and high alcohol, which is unreasonable at the point of progression, she can stay for a few meals depending on luck, kicking her out will ruin the combo which seems unfavourable; during the re-challenge of the final mission, phase 2 can be completely luck dependant as you can get some really unfavourable spell debuffs that halt the run, preventing you from collecting spellcards, the final phase seems to be a little luck dependant too, it requires you to give perfect meals, but the guest will sometimes only ask for normal meals, which means the bar will not go up, it can really screw over the run sometimes.[/spoiler]
-[spoiler]I would also like to see a little bit more post game content as well, there isn't really much to do after the final mission. There isn't really much of a use for the funds either after the final payment. The funds just sit there. I would also like to see more sparrow levels or a way to upgrade the sparrow tune chance to 100% 
There are some scenarios where you can get extremely unlucky and have to sit through many seconds of the sparrow tune minigame for higher level foods, it can be a slog sometimes.[/spoiler]

Overall it is an amazing and enjoyable game, props to the developers, they did an amazing job. Sorry if the format or grammar isn't as great. I'm not very used to writing reviews, but I'd love to express my gratitude and experience of the game. I'm really interested in what other areas, the developers have in store for the next DLCs. Thank you for reading this review and have a nice day.

A surprisingly complex, polished and engaging restaurant sim.  This is normally not a style of game I enjoy at all, but I gave it a shot due to the highly positive reviews, cute art and touhou characters.  What I found was an astonishingly engaging and rewarding game on top of that cute art.  The story is reasonably well written and the gameplay is engaging without being either simplistic or overwhelming.  The game tests both your memory and your reflexes with an overwhelming number of tasks and details to keep in mind, but also let you pause and review an ingame notebook full of recipes, preferences character notes and so on at any time, meaning the game is exactly as challenging as you want it to be, tempered only by your patience.

The game does a great job of explaining itself and conveying its characters and is packed with details, characterizations and references that will amuse any tohou fan.  Strongly recommended even, or perhaps especially if you usually only play the bullet hells.

Personally, I think this game is great. It has a unique story, great art, and fun gameplay. However, there are a few balancing issues that I personally think hurt the experience, and would like to see changed.

1: Tewi
Currently, I think Tewi is currently unfair to the player, as the only ways to avoid having your combo broken is to either get lucky and have Reimu visit your restaurant first, or to fork over ridiculous amounts of money. While I think Tewi's concept is good, I think her prices are way too high. I believe that Tewi would feel fair if she sold common items for a much lower (but still fairly high) amount. For example, 1 egg for 200 yen. I feel that this would make the option of buying from Tewi to avoid a broken combo actually viable, and give the player another option than simply relying on RNG to have Reimu come first.

2: Pacing
In its current state, I feel that it takes far too long to make story progress. Often, I will have reached the amount necessary to pay off my debt and still be required to stay at my current point in the game for around 10 more days. While I recognize the importance of the scripted story events, I wish they would all simply happen in order once you unlock a new location, then allow you the option to pay off your debt and move to the next location once that section's story has been completed or allow you to continue until the deadline. I feel that would greatly improve the pacing of the game, allowing skilled players to avoid stagnation while still giving less skilled players time to pay off their debt.

3: Fast Travel
As it stands, the fast travel system feels useless. Far-away areas like the Palace of Earth Spirits and Youkai Mountain feel inaccessible, as by the time you reach them, it's almost time to open your Izakaya. I feel that this system should be changed so that it takes one hour to fly anywhere, making distant locations explorable and giving a reason to walk to nearby destinations.

4: Frog Shrine
Personally, I love cosmetics and unlockable content. However, I hate this game's system of unlocking them. I feel that having to spend two hours praying to the shrine for 4 coins when unlockables cost upwards of 20 is unbalanced and consumes an unreasonable amount of the player's time. I believe it should be adjusted so the first prayer gives you four or five coins, and each consecutive prayer gives you one coin and a random item from the shrine's item pool. I feel that this would allow players who want the unlockables to obtain them without sacrificing large amounts of their very limited time to unlock them, and give players who want them ASAP the option to sacrifice more time to get them slightly faster.

5: Reimu's Dialogue
Personally, I don't like Reimu's "ghosts and spirits" line because it makes me fear for the safety of my beloved Yuyuko. This one's completely personal preference and is probably something only I care about.

Overall, I think this game is great, but could be made even better with a few tweaks.

This is how you do a Touhou Fan Game Right. And by that I mean taking the concept of the everyday life of the world and turn a casual game idea (Like Diner Dash) into a whole system of working in special orders among managing funds. This game is by far the highest rated Fan Game I can give it even surpassing previous endeavors.

This game is crazy long as well. At the time of my review I put in over 34 HOURS (Due to reading dialogue and side quests) and have yet to really see the end of the game at all. It's an addictive loop of gathering Ingridients, picking where to set up based on what side quests you have/Main Quest and then setting a menu up that appeals to the locals based on Price and the flavors the normal and potential guests can bring. The music is sweet, charming and dare I say 'Nostalgic' in some tracks that brings a sweetness to the ears. It might sound weird but I like listening to the music while I cook too. Brings a smile to my face.

The art style to some may come off as Retro but i rather call it by it's actual name 'Pixelated'. The small sprites on the overworld look cute and chibi but the full pixel illustrations carry a lot of charm and love for each character you meet in the series. Added on the fact you can change Mystia's outfit with unlocks and gifts too!
Side quests also offer unlockable modifiers if you max out your relationship ranks with certain customers and many benefits to learning new recipes that may just net you that much more money you require to pass.

The price it offers alongside the DLC (Which just adds even more to do) is both amazing and kind of concerning. I wouldn't even be mad if I paid $30 for this game. It's that high in quality compared to other Touhou Fan games and games in general of it's caliber. 

Should you buy it? Yes. Give it a try if you never played a game like this or play it if you love the games where you complete orders (Adding extra for bonuses too) for customers. It costs just about the same as a Mcdonald's Combo Meal but leaves you satisfied for days to come! So what are you waiting for!? Come help out a cute Night Sparrow fulfill her dreams and open a concert while serving customers along the way, maybe even save Gensokyo!

It's rare for me to get sucked into singleplayer games like this, but this is one of the rare ones that both holds my attention for hours on end, and can bring me back in even after weeks of not playing. There are extremely few games I could think of that have this much heart put into them, and it really shows. The artwork is all so cute, the music is very good (and has references to official Touhou themes if you can pick them out), everyone has so much character... There are just so many good things to say.
For how cheap this game is, it is absolutely worth the price any day of the week. I didn't hesitate to buy the DLCs when I learned they existed, cause I would have gladly paid the full price for just the base game. I haven't done much in either yet, I'll admit. But it's already clear there's just as much love put into them as the main game, and they way they're worked in doesn't feel forced.
I will say- this game isn't perfect. I've come across a few small spelling errors, and a few graphical bugs (just minor stuff in the UI), but I feel like that's just part of the charm, honestly :)

[h1]7/10[/h1]

[b]Overall[/b]
An addictive restaurant management sim that's polished enough to hold interest, particularly if you enjoy the core gameplay loop of gathering ingredients, choosing what dishes to serve and making dishes to order. If you're a Touhou fan I expect you may get a bit more out of the story than I did as there is more dialogue than you might expect at first glance. I played mainly on Steam Deck which felt perfect for running a few nights of the izakaya while watching tv or on a break. Progress synced well enough that I could pick up on PC at other times without any worry. I really liked some of the art (particularly of all the different dishes!) and the music was pleasant, but may get a bit repetitive if you spend hours playing at a time. Very enjoyable if you're into casual management sims, and while it's sometimes a little rough around the edges I didn't notice any real bugs while playing. If you don't read Chinese make sure that any DLC you buy has an English release as they usually release in Chinese first - unless you want to muddle through in which case go for it! Dialogue may seem slightly wonky to English speakers but is plenty good enough to understand.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
Mainly focused around daytime gathering and talking to NPCs/buying from vendors, then running the izakaya at night. Daytime tasks are time-management focused with most actions taking 30 minutes. NPCs will give you tasks to complete which will reward you with new recipes or other useful upgrades (and story!). The izakaya management revolves around upgrading your locations/cooking tools, and serving endless streams of customers with a little cooking mini-game. You will eventually unlock things that make the day-time foraging and talking to people more efficient so you can focus on running the izakaya at night, but some of it is not very well signposted (at least in the English translation) so a guide can be helpful at times. There is also a main overarching story to complete, so the game is not endless (unless you want it to be..)

[b]Achievements[/b]
There are a fair amount of achievements you will get simply for playing the game. There was one where I needed to know in advance I would reload and make a different decision on a specific day, so if you're hunting for 100% completion you will want to look some of them up beforehand or risk having to replay if you don't have a save file from near that decision. Most are simply a case of playing long enough - I got to 100% achievement completion in about 80 hours but if you're more efficient you could definitely get there sooner. At the time of review I only own the base game and DLC1 so I can't comment on later DLCs.

The main game has a metric ton of content, and on top of that there are 2.5 DLCs available, with a third apparently in the works. I had never played a game even remotely similar to this--I had no idea what/who Touhou is--but I cannot. stop. playing.

Highly doubt you’ll be able to find many, if any, games with this much soul and content put into it for the price it’s listed as.
