The soundtrack is beyond godly and you can get the full set for a really great price as well. Waiting for the second dlc to get translated and I plan on getting it along with the last of the 3 ost parts I’m missing. Really awesome game that’s got pretty much all the core things you can ask for. Gameplay is top notch with a decently paced difficulty that’s not too demanding but requires focus, a wide array of melodic tunes to vibe to as you cook and sync with the rhythm mechanics, a delightfully written cast of characters from the Touhou universe, and a pretty lighthearted but interesting story. Don’t sleep on it, Mystia Izakaya is 100000% worth your time!

Game of the Year 2022 in my opinion.* Pixel art is fantastic, the music is stellar, the writing is great, at times hysterical, and the gameplay loop is relaxing but engaging. For the low price of $6, you're looking at about 35 hours of content, which is how long it took me to get through the base game. All the hours beyond that have been me powering through the DLC.

If I had any complaints:
[list]
     [*]The difficulty is somewhat all over the place. I easily blazed through the paywalls at the end of each chapter with well over 2-3 times the required amount of cash for each one. On the other hand, the boss fights, what few and far between they are, are ridiculously strict for how laid back the rest of the game is. The majority of the game, you more-or-less can take your time and can at times let your employees run the place, and once the bell rings midnight you can still serve whoever is left in your restaurant. However, once you get transported to the Netherworld, the game suddenly shifts to this harrowing, stressful environment where every second matters, and if you dawdle for even a moment, you will not make it, and to top it off, you do it [i]all by yourself.[/i] 

To put it simply, the game does a poor job at preparing you for the end-game story encounters.

     [*]Once you figure out how to satisfy every tag for the VIPs, there's very little incentive to switch up what you serve them. So instead of inventing new dishes every time I get a new order from a VIP, I can just serve her something that satisfies all of her preferences at once, which makes serving them feel a repetitive after awhile. When I see Patchouli walking into my restaurant, I know dang well she wants evening pancakes with bamboo and wagyu beef with a side of whiskey with occasional Ramune. Reimu wants riceballs with wagyu beef and honey. It makes it feel less like I'm serving them a improvised dish, and more like my VIPs are simply easy to please with having the same meal every time.

     [*]Lore is sometimes inconsistent with the source material. For instance, early on Mystia claims she is illiterate. This likely stems from her interview in [url=https://en.touhouwiki.net/wiki/Bohemian_Archive_in_Japanese_Red/Mystia][i]Bohemian Archive in Japanese Red[/i][/url] where she stated that she has difficulty reading small letters, to which Aya jokingly suggests that she cannot read at all. However, [i]Oriental Sacred Palace[/i] shows Mystia reading a book aloud while rubbing her eyes, so it's probably more likely that she has some kind of reading difficulty, rather than being outright illiterate. Thankfully, stuff such as this is simply minor and can be waved as artistic license.

     [*]The translation is normally great, but it could've used some refinement. Typos are abundant, and sometimes naming conventions are inconsistent, as if two different people translated this game without communicating. For example, in one instance the game referred to a location in the game as the "Scarlet Devil Mansion," which is what the place has been known as in English for decades, while in another case, the game referred to it as the "Scarlet [b]DEMON[/b] Mansion," which, while [i]technically[/i] an accurate translation, I have never seen it referred to as such in my years as a fan, and the inconsistency is jarring to say the least.

     [*]Another minor complaint: I do not care for the usage of current-day memes in the dialogue, because they will date this game so hard in 5-10 years. Hearing a horny goblin go on about how [i](ugh)[/i] "thicc" Meiling's thighs are is groan-worthy today, and it will be even more-so in the future when that vernacular dies off.
[/list]

But all of these are just minor road bumps in what has been, overall, and extremely pleasant experience. I've even been streaming the game to some Discord friends, and they can't seem get enough of it. One of them isn't even a Touhou fan, yet he finds the game absorbing, even going as far as to call it "a cozy slice-of-life." So don't just take my word for it that this game is 10/10 material.

*[i](Yes I know it came out in 2021, but the English version wasn't released until 2022.)[/i]

Cute Touhou fangame from a small developer, and the setting is used well for some incredibly pleasant and cute character work. Love seeing all the characters interacting mostly-peacefully, and seeing Mystia resolve the mild drama and build friendships by serving people food.

Story aside, this is also genuinely one of the most mechanically sound and well-designed shop sim games that I have seen, if arguably a bit too easy once you've leveled up a lot. Underneath the touhou fanservice are very smart shop sim design choices that add depth without sacrificing quality of life. Pinnacle of the genre, frankly.

The rhythm game elements I could take or leave, as I'm not good at rhythm games, but fortunately they're generally easy and straightforward, so it becomes a cute touch that I can still appreciate. Plus, at higher levels, you have to do them less and less. There is also a new dlc to make them harder for people who do actually like rhthym game stuff.

Cons: Controlling the UI can be a bit unintuitive sometimes, but not so bad that I can't just get used to it. And I trust the dev to keep improving on things.

This game has way more content than any $6 game should. I highly recommend it if you like cooking games or these sorts of management games. It does have a rhythm element, but they are basic and easy enough to pull off. But if you don't get the rhythm segments done consistently, it's not a huge deal either.

One thing I don't see mentioned in other reviews is how the game allows you to mostly play at your own pace. You unlock several locations with different preferences and famous patrons, and can adjust the amount of tables you have set up at the start of the day (you unlock more tables manually via quests and don't necessarily even have to do it). 

I myself don't have issue with the more bustling Izakaya, but this is a very safe recommendation to those who are intrigued by the cute artstyle and gameplay, who might be worried the game becomes too difficult. It doesn't if you don't want it to.

I'm over 14 hours in and it still feels like I've got a long way to go to complete it all. Highly recommended, you really couldn't get better for this price!

Sometimes I fantasize about Suika coming home drunk and beating me until I feel numb. She kicks me in the ribs until I can hardly breathe. Then she starts to cry and apologizes, begging me to forgive her. She holds me all night as I gently cry into her dress. Please help is there any hope for me.

Anyways, this is a very cute and chill cooking game, and pretty easy to get into even if you're not a big Touhou fan or don't know a ton about it like I as many of the characters are cute and charming in their own ways, and while it has some minor issues like overlaying text such as giant golden letters telling you your rewards will hang over textboxes for about a minute which is annoying at most, and in some tutorial bits it'll circle the wrong prompt if you're playing in English like me so a few tool tips and hotkeys will be off-centered or way too close to one another which make it hard to read and I do wish you could click out of everything instead of having use to key unless I missed something. 

But the Devs are aware of the issues and always making amends so it doesn't detract from the overall experience which is gathering ingredients or buying them with some time-management during the day to complete side-quest or invite certain guest so you can level up their bonds to learn more recipes for your shop, and then setting up shop and listening to some good tunes whilst making sure you keep your customers happy so they don't strike you down with the power of god and experiment with your recipes to learn what your quest like or don't whilst under the pressure of different events whether be owning a mortgage to a child or a god threatening your entire livelihood, and while the game can get hectic later on depending on how good of a cook and server you are, it's still a nice game to turn your brain off and chill as you make food you'll never taste in your life.

Mystia's Izakaya was a game I thought was going to be just casual and nothing big other than its gorgeous pixel art and sprites of the Touhou cast. I am glad to be wrong. When I found out how to appeal to customer's tastes by adding in different ingredients and being able to proc spell cards from the unique guests, I was stunned by the creativity you can put in making the dishes. 

For just being a diner-type game, I have had a lot of fun being overwhelmed by the mass amounts of customers and seeing all the different unique spell card effects. I still have plenty more to go but heck, this game is super worth it. It is one I'd recommend to new fans of the series who haven't played (or want to play) any of the mainlines. Honestly ranks up there with Luna Nights being a fantastic entry game into the series and its world. 

In my opinion, this is the best fan-game. And I'm a metroidvania fan who loved Luna Nights. Go serve some fried lamprey!! (Or something else since that usually runs out fast)

I only found this game because I was browsing the Points Shop and found the characters in one of the Steam profile backgrounds to be super cute. I researched the game and what I saw seemed to be adorable. I downloaded the game and immediately fell in love with the game play - it's simple enough to not be infuriating, but complex enough to keep you on your toes.

Each main character has a unique personality type that truly shines through, and befriending them all is part of the charm of this game - I can't wait to see what new dialogue I'll receive once I reach a milestone with one of the characters. 

All in all, I highly recommend this game. If you love things like Overcooked or Plate Up, you'll probably enjoy this. The relationship building between characters is reminiscent (to me, at least) of classic Harvest Moon games, only more rewarding. I can't wait for the English translation of DLC2 to be finished so I can dive into more characters and story!

Unironically my actual GOTY of this year so far. This is an absolutely lovely restaurant management game that oozes charm, has A LOT of content and a surprising amount of depth. The pixel art is really really cute and there's a lot of nice illustrations if you're into the style. Music is really nice and fitting to the game (there's even a surprising rhythm mini-game that **actually adapts to the game soundtrack**). Costing less than 5 euros, this game has no business being this good.

I honestly have no idea how they can allow themselves to sell a game this good for this cheap. If you're in the market for a cute and wholesome restaurant management game to kick back and relax with after a long day at work, you probably won't find anything better at this price, or probably even several times the price.

And if you're a Touhou junkie like me, you're probably already playing this and don't need me to tell you that this is amazing.

TL;DR - Easy base gameplay mechanics with advance play possibilities for those who like to kick it up a notch. Relax and enjoy, or buckle down and push yourself. The game is easy to pick back up when you have the itch to play it again after setting it down for a while.

The game has a core loop of collecting/buying materials, preparing meals for quests, setting up your shop and location, then opening up for the night. Serve customers to generate income to pay back your loan shark and restock your shop. Continued success leads to a larger shop with more seats and different areas to open up at which changes the frequency of the different types of guests. Changing food trends will also affect the types of dishes your customers will ask for adding a little bit of thought to be put into what exactly you want to stick on your limited amount of menu slots.

When running your restaurant you can either go solo or pay some of the in game inhabitants to help you with certain roles. Patrons order after they're seated and you fill the orders in real time, optionally making modifications based on the tastes of the individual diners to maximize their stay and empty their pockets while increasing the reputation of your brand. Special guests will sometimes appear, and making them dishes they like will give your shop useful boosts for the night, disappoint them and those spells end up letting you know their dissatisfaction.

There is an interesting variety of different dishes requiring different ingredients and cooking methods. You are in charge of what goes into the dish, while the actual cooking is done automatically, sometimes with a rhythm game thrown in which can give you a bonus effect. It is simple enough that you can just select the item and follow the ingredient list, but with enough customization that you can deviate and make your own creation to suit the guest's palate.

It would be nice to see more accurate prompts for controller users as sometimes the buttons displayed do not line up with what is in your actual hands, although the actual support for a controller is well done.

Overall, not a bad choice for the casual or seasoned gamer. Even people new to the Touhou fandom can get into this game as background knowledge is not really required for the most part to enjoy the gameplay or the main narrative. The game itself is not too hardware demanding either, opening it up to players that may not have the dedicated gaming power required for other games.

I don't often review games. When I do, it's normally because a game is so astoundingly brilliant I simply have to sing its praises. 

[h1] Overall [/h1]
Overall, this game is a labour of love that the devs obviously devoted a lot of passion into. Everything from the mechanics and music to the artwork blend together to create an absolutely riveting experience you just can't put down. 10/10.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]
It's a deep cooking and light business RPG on the surface, having you play as a 'youkai', a Japanese folklore demon, intent on running an 'izakaya', a Japanese street food and alcohol stand serving humans, youkai, fairies and spirits alike. 

The core gameplay loop has you roaming the beautiful land of Gensokyo during the day, collecting ingredients in a manner not unlike Stardew Valley or Harvest Moon's foraging mechanics. At sunset you plan your food and drinks menu based on what ingredients you have and open your stall. During the night you cook up meals, popping in and out of crafting menus to serve your customers Diner Dash style. There's a very light rhythm game element here where you can sing to your food to make it taste better, unlocking various buffs. The crafting system provides lots of room for personal touches and experimentation to create the perfect meal to please your customers. Get your food and drinks out on time and tailor them to your guests' tastes and the current trends and you get bonus tips. 

You don't have to go it alone either. As proprietress, you get to hire various story characters along the way and set them various duties during the night. And each of them are just as lovingly crafted, full of personality and character with their own storylines to boot. 

On top of that, there's a lovingly crafted visual novel style character interactions with a very colourful cast of humans, youkai and spirits that inhabit the land. This plays out during the day while you're roaming or during the night when they drop by your stall to partake in your food. This leads on to a very deep and rewarding relationship system that unlocks things from new recipes and ingredients to various buffs when you feed them the right dish at the right time. 

In short, this is Recettear, Stardew Valley, VA-11 HALL-A, Diner Dash brought together into a very cohesive game presented in Touhou trappings.

[h1] Artwork [/h1]
The absolutely stunning pixel art is simply popping with life and vibrancy, from the adorable character portraits with their alternate expressions and even costumes, to the beautiful backgrounds in the free roam segments to the gorgeous cut scene art. Not to mention the adorable little retro RPG sprites. 

[h1] Music [/h1]
The score is a great, fitting accompaniment to the game's style and feel sporting high quality production value. If you're into the Touhou franchise, you'll appreciate a lot of what's on offer here. 

[h1] Touhou [/h1]
If you don't know what Touhou is, that's okay, you'll still love this game, and through it you might discover this beautiful rabbit hole that is the Touhou franchise. But if you are a fan of Touhou, welcome home. This is the Gensokyo we love brought to life in what is clearly a love letter to the fandom. The music, the characters, the world, you are sure to love every bit of it.

This game is so incredibly fun. It's charming and cute and just has such a nice :) vibe to it. I'd pay about 15 dollars for the game.

The game is split between two main sections; an overworld gathering game where you can seek out quests and explore for new ingredients, and a resturant cooking sim. The act of cooking isn't difficult, but the complexity is quickly increased thanks to the addition of rhythm minigames when selecting a meal, as well as having the ability to add any ingredient to any meal to properly satisfy customers.

Some things aren't explained well, such as how earning money actually works (I'm not sure if adding an egg to a rice ball actually makes the rice ball any more expensive for instance), but it's very easy to learn in every other way.

Great amount of gameplay for the price - although it's pretty much the same gameplay for like 40-50 hours, several things are added in the spice it up. Great art, great music, great dialogue, great devs who keep their players in the loop. Very much worth it :)

TL;DR: Touhou Mystia's Izakaya is a charming and cute restaurant sim with a surprisingly interesting story and solid character design. 9/10 so far!

----

This game is a restaurant simulator, first and foremost, so you're going to be spending a lot of your time playing carefully thinking of the needs of every customer. The better the dish you serve (according to individual taste), the better the rewards. There are rare customers, which double as NPCs, who may request specific dishes with weird twists or help you add things to your menu! 

The more you play, the better your restaurant gets. From the looks of things, you can also expand out to other areas later on. Upgrades to the restaurant currently include extra cooking tool space and more seating. There is also an employee system that helps you automate some of the serving process. 

Every morning, before you open, you wake up and start gathering ingredients either through harvesting or by purchasing from a vendor. While you walk about, you may see some NPCs with quests for you; these requests are typically to gather specific items or cook certain dishes for delivery. Every time you engage with an NPC successfully, you level up the relationship you have with them a bit... which eventually leads to you getting new recipes and etc! 

The spritework is all quite nice so far, but the world design itself seems to be lacking some shadow work or something. Seems weirdly flat as you walk around. Otherwise, the 'cutscenes' are gorgeously done. 

I'm not familiar with whatever franchise this game actually comes from, but the character designs are quite interesting and they seem pretty well-written. It's interesting to run a restaurant in a world full of civilized yokai, who no longer have to eat exclusively humans. I haven't seen much of this land yet, but the worldbuilding is also quite solid so far.

Just picked this up through the Steam Summer Sale, with all of the game's DLC, for $9. This game is worth the money. It's cute, fun, and relaxing. Exactly the kind of thing I was looking for. It's somewhat similar to Stardew Valley, which is quite nice.

Fun basic gameplay of managing orders and cooking times, hectic but opening menus will freeze time. Named customers have specific requests and it feels good when you finally remember what they like and make it without checking. Even the unnamed NPCs have extra preferences you can cater to on top of their order!
Some menu items will get dozens of orders and others none - possibly based on the customers at each location. It's a puzzle to figure out a menu that's both popular and profitable.

Outside of restaurant management, Misty gathers ingredients and builds relationships to get recipes and perks. It does require some thinking to plan each day around quests and time-specific gathering. The main story progression is a little slow but there's still plenty to do.

Cheerful art and bgm, cozy atmosphere. It's probably more enjoyable if you have some knowledge of the Touhou world but not required.

The DLCs aren't necessary but do help fill out the space between main story events - if you're enjoying the game, feel free to pick it up mid-playthrough.

Excellent value for $5.99; feels more like a $20 game. As you play, new areas and mechanics open up, and there's a surprising amount of depth. Note that the game supports English, even though this wasn't labelled.

PROS:
- Fun gameplay loop. You collect ingredients for a few minutes, then run the izakaya.
- You can customize your dishes to satisfy the customers' tastes.
- Not too difficult; there's some challenge without it becoming frustrating. More fun than Overcooked.
- The dialog is all skippable, which is a blessing.

CONS:
- The UI takes some getting used to. There's a bug where you can't always rebind the keys.
- I can't tell the fox and cat customers apart.
- The art isn't the greatest; it's in that awkward zone where it's a little too big to be called pixel art, but not high resolution either. The still images are very nicely drawn, though.
- The music gets tedious.

Recently got into Touhou, so I don't know much about the characters. However, this game absolutely oozes charm, from the restaurant management to the character interactions.  I can tell the devs put a lot of time into this project and I couldn't be more satisfied with this purchase!

Honestly, I'm so glad Steam randomly recommended me this game. I'm also glad I actually decided to try it out, since I normally ignore most of the things I get recommended. I was initially enticed by the visually pleasing aesthetics and it being set out in the Touhou universe, but I did not expect much at first.

It didn't take me long to get invested and to like everything about the game more and more. The game is meant to be seen as a casual experience and every element of the game comes together to make this the best possible casual experience, from the beautifully done pixelated sprites, to the chill arrangements and wholesome character interactions and story. Putting my Touhou bias aside, I still think everything holds up and is very enjoyable even if you're not a fan of the universe/characters/music/games. 

The core gameplay loop is deceptively simple, and from my perspective, a bit stressful (wanting to remember everything a character likes/dislikes to eat in order to not have to check their information page every time, and also making sure there's no people waiting in line for a free table when the clock hits midnight (because they'll leave)), but still enjoyable and pretty addicting - keep the GRIND going for those ingredients and money.

Great game, definitely recommend it, especially considering its price tag. The dlcs are fun too, and I'm looking forward to the English localization of the second one. I just beat it a bit ago, and have been staying in Hakugyokurou, listening to its music ever since while writing this review.

Keep up the great work, I'm proud of you, don't let em get your kneecaps.

Touhou Mystia's Izakaya is a casual restaurant running game set in Touhou's Gensokyo. And it is definitely worth your time and money.

The story follows Mystia as she expands her business from a small food cart to multiple restaurants throughout the world, learning new recipes to sell and making new friends. And while doing this, there is a storyline that gives you a goal to keep coming back.

The main gameplay consists of two segments. One during the day where Mystia can gather resources, talk to friends and potential friends and shop for ingredients. The other during the evenings where she runs her business. She sets up her food cart and serves food and drink to the customers.
Normal customers will order from the menu, but the more interesting characters will not tell you exactly what they want. They'll give you hints and have their own preferences and then it is up to you to give them something you think they will like.

This makes for a solid gameplay loop that makes it easy to go just one more day, with just enough planning ahead to always feel like you're making more progress and getting better at everything by a little bit. 
Both art and music are pleasant to look at and hear.

It has a few small flaws, but none of them are in any way a big problem. The worst I've seen was text not fitting in the dialog box and a few untranslated lines that were not relevant to the plot. Oddly the game seems to stop responding when the button to exit to desktop is pressed, but at that point it's not really a problem anyway.

In conclusion, Touhou Mystia's Izakaya is amazing value for your money and a title I will remember fondly. There are very few flaws and while the gameplay may be somewhat simple everything combines into a great experience overall.

A restaurant simulator with elements from resource management, village life simulation, and (lightly) from rhythm games. The rhythm game component is very lightweight and serves as a mechanic for getting various boosts to your restaurant, such as being able to toss your orders to a table instead of having to walk it out. Edit: I also purchased this game after the English translation came out. The translation from Chinese to English is more than serviceable, although there are a few typos and grammatical errors out there. It contains a significant amount of dialogue, so props go to the translators for their efforts.

The resource management has you making serious considerations as to where you want to spend your limited time per day, as every action (besides talking) takes 30 minutes and you have 8 hours to prepare for your night's opening. Some resources are only available at certain times of day, while other resources are unavailable at shops, and the ever-growing crowd of customers can drain your supply if you don't dedicate time to gathering those resources.

The village life simulation is fairly lightweight, where talking to the various major and minor (named) characters unlocks quests, which can provide new recipes or upgrades for your restaurant. New dialogue with these characters can also be obtained through improving your relationship, if that's your thing. Being a Touhou fan game, there are references to the official media and some fan theories throughout. The game is enjoyable without knowledge of Touhou, but being familiar with the setting absolutely enhances the experience.

The restaurant simulation is where it's at though. It's fairly simple: a customer orders a dish and drink, and you provide them what they want. If you want to make a bit more in customer tips, you can add an ingredient with qualities that the customer likes during the cooking process to tailor it to that customer's style. As your recipe list grows, you have to decide what you want to serve (or not serve) each night based on your resources and your customers, as well as which cooking implements and how many you want to bring along. Fortunately, time stops while you're looking at the menus and while choosing ingredients for a dish, so it's not impossible to handle everything even if you have 6 dishes lined up and waiting.

The real meat of the game is in the named characters that appear. Instead of asking for a dish and drink directly, they will give you a description of the dish and drink they want (ie. "I want something that's cut in small portions" and "I'd like a drink that's very stong"). It's up to you to study these characters and their likes and dislikes and provide them a dish and drink that fits their preferences. If your service pleases them enough, they will use a "spell card", which triggers bonuses like giving you extra ingredients or increasing customer draw for a short time. To add further complexity, each character has a certain budget. While you can serve them anything that fits their tastes, if you make them spend their entire budget in one meal, they'll just up and leave after eating.

Lastly: the music. The overworld music is charming, but the restaurant is where you'll spend most of your time. The music starts off quiet and steady as customers start filtering in, and the music will dynamically change and become more upbeat and energetic as the restaurant gets more busy. The various locations' tracks are very good quality and make for great listening in-game and out.

In short, if you like casual cooking games and aren't turned off by the artwork and aesthetics, there's plenty to like about this game. At the time of writing I'm 23 hours in and am just over half-way through the game, though I make an effort to talk to everybody and complete whatever quests I can.

The translation isn't perfect, but this is an incredibly engaging game with a gameplay loop that starts off simple but gets more and more complex and frantic as you get further in. You start just serving simple dishes to a handful of people, but it soon escalates and you have to keep in mind a whole lot of things ranging from your relationship with important guests, their preferences, the constant drain of money from buying more resources and the inevitable deadlines, and the never-ending onslaught of people to serve. It's still not the most difficult game, but it gets genuinely frantic if you're aiming for the most cash each night! 

On top of that the game has beautiful music and pixel art and looks adorable. I recommend this entirely if you're in the mood for something relaxed, but not too relaxed.

I purchased and have to say it's pretty fun! The story is, in order to save your friend's kneecaps, you take out a loan and to pay said loan you have to manage an Izakaya! There are some characters in Gensokyo you can talk to, by talking to them you increase their affection(?) towards you. You can gain more recipes through talking to them and giving them good food based on their prefrences. Talking about prefrences, each characters have preferences which reflects upon characters e.g. Reimu like cheap food cause she's dirt poor :) . I don't want to spoil more about the gameplay mechanics because you should buy it to know more. 
Conclusion, it's a quality game for it's price.
P.S. this gamed made me fall into Touhou in general.

So this is kinda my first experience with the Touhou Project as a whole, besides hearing the song Bad Apple. 

As someone who doesn't know the characters, the back story, the years of history etc etc etc of Touhou. This game is really enjoyable and in my opinion, dare I say, even under priced for what it is. 

The core loop of the game is basically you have two phases of the day. First phase is basically, the day time where you can talk with other characters, accept/complete side quests, collect ingredients etc. The evening/night time is when you open your Izakaya (or a restaurant type place) and serve customers with varying degrees of ease or difficulty pending what you have available to you. That's basics of this game, but what an enjoyable experience I've had. Yes, there's a story and background lore/development. But really it's the game play loop of collecting ingredients and serving food will be the catalyst on whether someone enjoys the game or not.

The art style is nice, the music is wonderful and the game is just fun in my opinion. At some point in the future I plan on buying the DLCs for this game. Once it gets a translation. First DLC of is supposedly gonna be translated by May 2022, which is apparently when a second DLC is coming out.

The only flaws of the game is that a couple parts of the game haven't been translated or it's a minor bug where the English version of the text doesn't appear so you get the Chinese (I think it's Chinese, could be wrong) version of the text instead. The other flaw for me being that there is a bit too much text dialogue. To compare it to another game, Stardew Valley, if you chat to an NPC you get one or two bits of dialogue and then you move on. This game has quite a bit more than that even when you're just chatting to an NPC. Which is great for someone who enjoys those interactions between characters to deepen the lore/relationships. But that's just not for me who prefers a quick text and then being able to move on.

Overall, the game probably has about 20-40 hours worth of content in the base game, depending how much dialogue you read, how quickly you progress through the days, how often you looks at recipes when cooking, how many side quests you do etc etc. So yeah, totally worth buying at full price.

_________________________________________________________

OLD REVIEW: 

Seeing quite a few questions related to whether the English localization is necessary to play this game (DO NOTE, ENG and JP localization are scheduled to come already, this is for the ppl that want to dive right in without waiting, me included) so I figured I'd just write this review.

About the game first:
The game's good, filled with content, and mind you I fast-forwarded all the story because I couldn't read any, so there could've been more hours invested. 
OST is great and defo among the highlight of the game. I even got the OST DLC (I think there are some tracks missing from it, but most are included). 
Gameplay is intuitive, snappy, and haptic. I really do feel like an (albeit failing) masterchef contestant dishing out hundreds of delicacies by the second. (You can pause time by the way, by opening up any UI, this game won't be troubling)
Still buggy however, on some occasions I had to restart that whole cooking day. But well it's an early access title so I'll be more lenient.


k, now can u play without knowing Chinese? my experience (I speak eng and jpn)

short answer: possible gameplay wise if u put in effort ALT TABbing. possible story-wise too if you like to waste time with OCR and deepl/google trans (and it won't be quality trans either). I don't feel it's worth it for lots of people, just wait for localization.

long answer: at a basic level and during the beginning serving nights, it's very intuitive to understand collecting ingredients, serving, cooking, etc. because there are detailed, pictoral instructions on the screens, gotta be pretty hard to not be able to learn to serve common guests (there are pictures of dishes)
however, as soon as the first "bulli" barges in and orders her way, it's a must you're able to read their requests, memo their favorites and dislikes (no dish pics), lest you anger them and they chase away your other customers (among many other things). Also, playing the game you must understand some quest objectives, current newspaper trend, etc. to even advance. Guides could help with the first, but I don't think there's any out there rn that details all quests (important ones at least, I think there will be one soon?). 
and ofc the story and lore. idk abt u guys but I love reading food tooltips/item descs. 
with Japanese u might be able to play normally (in this game you serve foods, and drinks. I understand all the drink cues (for english players just look for similar tags, it takes more time though) and most of the food cues (food cues are usually lengthy) but still the story was lost on me. Will replay when localization is out.

with that said yeah, you pretty much have to OCR and deepl a lot if you want to understand the story. gameplay wise it's not TOO bad with a good memory and guides, but make no mistake it will be a chore to a lot of people, having to ALT TAB back n forth. I used these guides:

ENG guide: https://steamcommunity.com/app/1584090/discussions/0/5081733371359110493/
CN guide (but it's an infographic so there's not much need to be able to read here, just tag comparing at most): https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2620805043

While the powerful inhabitants of Gensokyo compete for political influence and fight annual Gensokyo-threatening incidents, a little night sparrow is focusing on the smaller things. I give this game props for making me wonder for the first time what the weak youkai are up to while Reimu and co. are dealing with the classic wacky Touhou phenomenons (lol).

As for the game itself, it's a great chill game that's easy to jump in and out of. The English translation is just passable, but the daily food-stall-managing gameplay loop is both simple and addicting. Seeing familiar Touhou characters visit your stall feels almost like running into old friends. Normally I'm not super interested in Touhou fangames, but I think this one has a great balance of uniqueness and identity while keeping loyalty to the source material.

虽然我不懂东方，但是我懂开饭堂！

I have already completed the game months ago in Chinese. Now that the English version is out, I've decided to rewrite the review for the new non-Chinese speaking players.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
It's a business simulation game. It's casual, easy to learn and addictive. Its core gameplay mechanic, which is cooking, offers enough diversity and challenge, but also keeps itself simple, so it never feels grindy or repetitive. 

There aren't many cooking games out there, and the ones I've played over the years are either too complicated to be enjoyable (looking at you Cooking Simulator) or offers too little so they get boring really fast, like a lot of those mobile games. Mystia's Izakaya easily stands out in this genre as a game I think fans of cooking games can enjoy.

[h1]Art[/h1]
I mean, just look at it. It's absolutely amazing. It retains the unique artstyle used in this dev's previous games. The character portraits, sprites and CGs all show a lot of passion poured into them by the artist. 

[h1]Music[/h1]
Of course a Touhou game cannot be without great soundtracks, but this game cranked it up a notch and produced some of the best video game music ever. 

Like, seriously. The music is way too good. Every new area to explore or setup shop in offers a pleasant surprise with its music, and I just can't praise it enough.

[h1]Story & Characters (no spoilers)[/h1]
This game offers an easy-to-follow, short and cute story that revolves around Mystia, whom you play as. That should already spark interest for any Touhou fan since she's such a minor character in the franchise and not much was ever revealed about her. 

It also stars many characters that rarely make an appearance even in fan games, such as Wriggle and Kyouko, offering more interesting perspectives to the world of Gensokyo.

The characters' designs and their lines are all very faithful to their source material. The characters' quirks are often accurately reflected through their dining preferences, making getting to know these characters a fun and immersive experience for Touhou fans. 

A lot of the dialogues and lines are simply hilarious (like most of Yuyuko's lines) and will certainly get a good chuckle out of you if you know the related Touhou lore. Even if you aren't a Touhou fan, I'm sure it's at least a fun read.

[h1]Replayability[/h1]
This is one of the most replayable games I have ever played.

I beat the game about 40 hours in, and spent another 40 hours playing. Now that there's a DLC, I can only imagine that number going up a few dozens more. I didn't play this game necessarily for achievements or unlockables, although they are available, but because I wanted to play it for some casual fun. I feel that's incredibly rare in this day and age for a non-multiplayer, non-roguelike game.

Maybe you won't enjoy the game as much as I did after completing everything, but completing the game alone is worth way more than this game costs.

Also apparently the devs being keen on further updating and expanding the game with QOL changes, holiday events and DLC content. They are very passionate towards this project. I'm sure there is still much more to come in this already rich and polished game.

[h1]About bugs and translation[/h1]
Other than Wriggle being in the game, the game is pretty much bug-free. It's possible that you run into one or two in your entire playthrough, but nothing serious.

Translation wise, I don't know because I haven't played it in English. Seeing some of the existing English reviews, it's probably okay.

[h1]Verdict[/h1]
This is a very special and charming game. For me, just standing behind the counter watching the izakaya in motion, observing customers come and go, enjoy their meals, is a satisfying, worthwhile experience. I believe both fans of Touhou and fans of cooking games will be able to share this feeling.

I remember first hearing about this game and not expecting much from it about 5 months ago. I never thought it would end up being one of my most played games on Steam. 

With that I can safely say this is one of the best games I have ever played. 

It is also the only Touhou game I have successfully convinced several non-Touhou-fan friends to play and enjoy. That's quite an achievement in itself.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
[h1]游戏性[/h1]
游戏的类型是经营模拟，主要的游戏内容是结识不同的客人，给不同需求的客人做菜。休闲，简单易懂，容易上瘾，也没有很肝很枯燥的感觉。

如果玩过20年前软星出品的《仙剑客栈》，其相似之处显而易见，但这作只是很大程度上还原了《仙剑客栈》的那种开着自己的店、与有趣的NPC们交谈、看着客人来来往往的舒适和成就感，而游戏性侧重点不同：没有复杂的迷宫探索，而是在城镇里与NPC对话进展剧情，并且做菜作为核心玩法，需要你逐渐熟知每道菜的材料、特性以及每位常客的口味，真的有一种小吃摊老板娘的代入感。

对东方厨（真就东方[b]厨[/b]呗，笑死）和喜欢做饭类游戏的玩家来说，这作绝对是非常出众、值得一试的。

[h1]美术[/h1]
这游戏的画风真的一级棒，与作者的先前作品相似，很令人舒适。无论是立绘、行走图还是CG都可以看出画师的热爱。

[h1]音乐[/h1]
说实话，第一次听到兽道营业的BGM我真是惊了，随后每到一个新地区探索或者开店时我都会惊一次。作曲质量真的非常非常高。

[h1]剧情人物相关（无剧透）[/h1]
剧情很简单明了，也不是很长，而且主角是小夜雀！能从小夜雀的视角探索观察幻想乡，这就已经很新鲜了。而且游戏里还有很多即使是同人游戏里也不常见的角色，比如莉格露和响子（甚至还有冴月麟，我超？），可以说是棒上加棒。

人物设计和对话都非常忠于原作，可以看到很多好玩的梗，而且角色的各种设定也都被融入到菜品酒水喜好中了。作为东方厨，看到这些都会会心一笑吧。

有很多对话和台词都很欢乐，比如幽幽子的大部分台词（当你给幽幽子上黑暗物质时）。即使不了解东方，这作的诙谐幽默也足以不会让阅读剧情感到枯燥。

[h1]重复可玩性[/h1]
这是我玩过重复可玩性最强的游戏之一了。我通关时大概是40小时，通关后又玩了40多个小时。现在有了DLC，还要再玩几十个小时无疑了。不光是为了解锁成就和一些物品，更多的是真的就是觉得很好玩。作为一款不是肉鸽，也不是联机的游戏，我觉得能让人一直有兴趣玩下去真的很少见。

即使你通关之后就不玩了，这个游戏的流程也绝对远远超值于它的价格。

而且作者一直在推出更新、节日活动和DLC，即使通关也还有越来越多的内容。

[h1]评价[/h1]
非常特别的一款游戏。

我很喜欢东方，也一直想找一款好玩的做饭题材的游戏。去年刚刚知道这部游戏的时候，我感觉我会喜欢，但也只以为是个流程很短的小游戏，完全没想到竟然会成为我游戏时间最长的游戏之一。

这也是我见过唯一一款推荐给不是东方众的朋友之后他们真的会玩而且喜欢的东方同人游戏。我觉得这就足以证明它有多特别了。

不管你是不是东方众，我都极力推荐。

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

I read some reviews saying this game is bare-bones, or there’s very little content, which I think stems from the fact that there’s not English language available for the game. As a diehard Touhou fan and a person who speaks Mandarin, I’ll try my best to do this game justice. WARNING: probably a biased review.

[h1]Backstory[/h1]

You play as Mystia Lorelei, a Night Sparrow that runs a food stand at the Youkai Trail in Gensokyo selling grilled lamprey. Your close friend, Kyouko Kasodani, a Yamabiko, is in deep trouble. She owes the Yakumo family a sum of 5000円, and the debt collector Chen has been harassing her about it. You offer to take up her debt and help her repay it before the next deadline.

[h1]Game mechanics[/h1]

[b]Gathering Ingredients[/b]
Pretty self-explanatory, you’ll need to gather ingredient for your dishes scattered throughout the map. You start every morning at 1000, and gathering each ingredient advances the time by 30 minutes. Ingredient gathering ends at 1800, which is when you open your shop. After a few days, you’ll be able to buy ingredients from a shop or receive quests from certain characters.

[b]Planning the menu[/b]
Usually depends on the amount of ingredients you have, the kitchenware you need and the profit from each dish. You don’t want to run into a situation where you run out of a certain dish and a customer orders it. That would result in them leaving. Also, after the first few days, you’ll start to receive the newspaper, which will detail the current trend in food in Gensokyo. Customers will be more likely to order food that follows the trend.
Planning the utensils is especially important, since you can make food, even if it is not on the menu. You’ll most likely need it for special customers, which I’ll touch on later.

[b]Running the food stand[/b]
Pretty straightforward at first, the customers come, they give you their order, you make the food, bring a drink and serve the meal to them. Ordinary customers will only order what’s on the menu. After the first few days, you’ll gain the ability to sing. Singing while preparing food increases the chances of getting a buff (Can serve food from anywhere, customers patience won’t decrease, etc.) You close the food stand at 0000, and proceed onto the next day.

[h1]Special Customers[/h1]

[b]Ordering[/b]
This is what makes the game way more deeper and interesting in my opinion. There are certain characters that won’t order from the menu known as special customers. Instead, they will tell you what kind of food and drink they want. For example, a character like Chen might tell you she wants fish, because she’s a cat. That means you’ll need a meal that has the seafood tag (海产). Every dish in the menu has multiple tags, so you’ll can try to match the request of the special customer to the tag in the dish. And maybe she wants a fruity drink, so you’ll need to search for a drink with the fruits tag (水果).

Knowing which customer might come is an important part of planning what kind of kitchenware to use. For example, Rumia might ask for something that is filling (饱腹). Let’s say you do not have the rice ball in your menu, which has the filling tag. However, you have a cutting board, which means you can still make a rice ball using the correct ingredients, even if it is still not on the menu. In the future, you might want to add dishes that require a cutting board to make when you’re opening shop in the Youkai Trail, which is where Rumia frequents.

[b]Adding ingredients to the dish to suit the customer’s preference[/b]
There’s a section in your journal that records the preferences of each special customer that you’ve met at least once for easy reference. Referring to the journal pauses your game, so you can take your time to plan out what dish to make.

You can add additional ingredients to add tags to your dishes. Back to the Rumia example, she might order something that is filling (饱腹). However, you notice upon reading your journal that she also likes meat (肉). Usually, you make a rice ball by using 1 unit of seaweed. However, you can add meat to the recipe to create a riceball with the meat tag. That way, you can have both tags in one dish. 

[b]Satisfaction level[/b]
By giving special customers what they like, you can raise their satisfaction level. If they are extremely satisfied with a meal, some special customers might give you additional buffs. On the flipside, if they are dissatisfied, they might debuff you instead. Raising their satisfaction level will increase their friendship with you, which might lead to them giving you new recipes the next time you meet them while you’re out gathering ingredients.

[h1]Story[/h1]

The story is pretty light-hearted so far. There are only two parts in the story, which should last you a few hours. After all, it's still in early access. The game unlocks the other 3 areas for you after you’ve completed all available story content. The game starts out slow at first, but it starts getting more complicated when you reach the second area in the story.

[h1]Art[/h1]

The artstyle is cute and charming, and the music is great. Suits a more light-hearted game like this one. What's not to love?

[h1]TLDR[/h1]

Buy it if you’re a Touhou fan. If you’re not a Touhou fan, maybe wait for an English patch if you’re interested in the game before you decide.

I've barely even played much of this game yet, but this one is really a shining star of non-danmaku Touhou fangames. 好

I'm not exactly sure why somebody said this game is bare-bones, they probably haven't even played an hour yet. There's a lot of story and it's quite fun, you have to understand the things that certain characters like, pay attention to the time for different ingredients, pair up the right utensils to create a good selection just in case a new character comes up, and test and try out a whole bunch of different things to get the right method down. There is a lot of story that you *can* go through, but you can also skip it. It's visuals and soundtrack is great, it's fun to play, and there is a lot to discover. The only issue is that there are quite a few bugs, which is understandable for an early access game. Thanks for another great game, I'll be updating this if my feelings change, or if I want to add anything.

The game is, as same as the devs said, a barebone concept demo at best, but they apparently had art assets ready at launch level and they are just so bloody nice to look at - you literally can't find another touhou fangame that has this level of polishing when it comes to art and UI alone. I don't know if this is going to be a fun game, but it's gonna be a beautiful one for sure.

That being said, I don't think that this "game" is worth buying or playing at the moment, as it's not really a game yet. All you can do here is to interact with random objects to get ingredients that have nothing to do with your current recipes with the miniscule matching game like a 3-year-old matching food names with flashcards. The current state is more like an art book in executable and I got bored after 10 minutes. The thumbs-up here is just showing my support for its ongoing development.

For those you who are not buying because of the language, you aren't really missing anything. The game doesn't have any real stories yet, and the only part that does require you to read is when special requests come in, which currently doesn't really matter as much anyway. Put it on your wishlist and stay toned for future updates.
